Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a cardiac arrest and was resuscitated, and is now intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current status is:

* Respiratory: He is on pressure support ventilation and is being weaned off the ventilator. His respiratory status declined last night, and he has a high respiratory rate.
* Neurological: He is agitated and has a decreased level of consciousness. His MRI showed no signs of acute ischemia, and his EEG shows possible seizure activity.
* Hemodynamic: He has labile blood pressures, with episodes of hypotension and hypertension. He is receiving labetalol and has a central venous catheter (CVC) in place.
* Infectious: He has a fever and has been treated with antibiotics for a possible infected line/bacteremia.
* Renal: He is on continuous dialysis and has a CVC in place. His creatinine levels are elevated, and he has a high blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level.
* Endocrine: He has hyperparathyroidism, likely secondary to his renal failure.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status has declined, and he may require further support or intubation.
* Neurological complications: The patient's agitated state and possible seizure activity may lead to further neurological deterioration.
* Hemodynamic instability: The patient's labile blood pressures may lead to further episodes of hypotension or hypertension.
* Infectious complications: The patient's infected line/bacteremia may lead to further sepsis or organ failure.
* Renal complications: The patient's chronic renal failure may lead to further decline in renal function, and he may require further dialysis.
* Endocrine complications: The patient's hyperparathyroidism may lead to further complications, such as bone disease or cardiovascular disease.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Respiratory support: The patient will continue to receive pressure support ventilation and will be weaned off the ventilator as his respiratory status improves.
* Neurological support: The patient will continue to receive sedation and analgesia, and his neurological status will be closely monitored.
* Hemodynamic support: The patient will continue to receive labetalol and will be monitored for further episodes of hypotension or hypertension.
* Infectious treatment: The patient will continue to receive antibiotics for his infected line/bacteremia.
* Renal support: The patient will continue to receive dialysis and will be monitored for further decline in renal function.
* Endocrine support: The patient will continue to receive treatment for his hyperparathyroidism, and his endocrine status will be closely monitored.

   Assessment and Plan
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest
   .
   # Respiratory failure.  He was originally intubated in setting of
   arrest with possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT
   chest and has had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear
   whether he truly has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
   negative to date.
   - Continue with ventilation.  Will likely not be able to think of
   extubation until patient
s mental status improves.
   - Cannot have CVVH today because of  HD catheter malfunction.  Renal
   notified and feel this is fine for today and they will reassess
   tomorrow.
   - Continue to do daily RSBI / SBT
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  It has recently been difficult
   to assess his mental status because he is so agitated when we lighten
   sedation.  His MRI, though severely limited by motion artifact, did not
   show any signs of acute ischemia.  His EEG reads show possible seizure
   activity.
   - We will try to sedate him as much as possible with just propofol and
   small amounts of fentanyl; he is not tolerating the lowering of
   fentanyl well
   - Continue to try Lidocaine oral spray to see if he can tolerate the
   ETT tube
   - F/u Neurology recs.
   - start  Keppra when off propofol
   - consider haldol instead of fentanyl in the future
    .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   .
   # Fever: Patient
s fever curve is improving now with lines removed
   (some low grade fevers overnight)  Dialysis line is growing
   micrococcus.
   - ID believes cefepime will suffice for treatment.  As this was an
   infected line/bacteremia, we should cover with 14 days of adequate
   antibiotics.
   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid pending ID input.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF
   unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Restarted back on
   CVVH after getting new lines placed, yesterday many liters negative.
   Don't feel that we need to be as aggressive with fluid removal as he is
   about 14L negative through LOS.   Will have to await a new line before
   proceeding with dialysis
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Not clinically significant at this point.
   - Restart Calcitriol
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile
   .
   #  UTI. Borderline UA. Culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2
   morphologies.  Sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
   - Continue Cefepime.  Has now completed 7d course but will continue due
   to persistent fevers.
   .
   # ?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus. Another 20 minute EEG was done this
   morning  Neuro has said that at this point it is likely encephalopathy,
   but may be some seizure activity.  Recommended starting Keppra when
   Propofol off
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease
   - continue to monitor.
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male who suffered a PEA arrest while in the ICU for respiratory failure and acute renal failure (ARF) following a cardiac transplant. He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) requiring chronic hemodialysis. He was recently treated for a line infection with cefepime and linezolid.

Current Status:

* The patient remains intubated and ventilated due to respiratory failure and altered mental status.
* He has a fever curve that is improving, and his lines have been removed.
* He has a micrococcus line infection, which is being treated with cefepime and linezolid.
* He has ARF, which is being managed with continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).
* He has anemia, which is being monitored.
* He has oral secretions, which are being managed with suctioning.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is a concern, and he may require continued sedation and monitoring.
3. Line infection: The patient has a micrococcus line infection, which may require continued treatment with antibiotics.
4. ARF: The patient's ARF is a concern, and he may require continued management with CRRT.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is a concern, and he may require continued monitoring and treatment.
6. Fever: The patient's fever is a concern, and he may require continued treatment with antibiotics.
7. Oral secretions: The patient's oral secretions are a concern, and he may require continued suctioning and management.
8. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular instability is a concern, and he may require continued monitoring and treatment.
9. Neurological sequelae: The patient's neurological sequelae from the PEA arrest are a concern, and he may require continued monitoring and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation to manage the patient's respiratory failure.
2. Continue sedation and monitoring to manage the patient's altered mental status.
3. Continue treatment with antibiotics for the line infection.
4. Continue management with CRRT for the patient's ARF.
5. Continue monitoring and treatment of the patient's anemia.
6. Continue treatment with antibiotics for the patient's fever.
7. Continue suctioning and management of the patient's oral secretions.
8. Continue monitoring and treatment of the patient's cardiovascular instability.
9. Continue monitoring and treatment of the patient's neurological sequelae.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who had a cardiac arrest and is currently intubated in the ICU. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on pressure support ventilation and is expected to remain intubated until his mental status improves.
* Altered mental status: The patient is agitated and has had difficulty assessing his mental status due to sedation. His MRI and EEG show possible seizure activity.
* Labile blood pressures: The patient has had intermittent hypotension and hypertension, which may be due to hypovolemia or an infectious source.
* Fever: The patient's fever curve is improving, and the ID believes that cefepime will suffice for treatment of the infected dialysis line.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure (ARF) on top of his chronic ESRD, and his etiology is unclear. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).
* Endocrine: The patient has elevated PTH, which is likely secondary or tertiary due to renal failure. He is being restarted on calcitriol.
* RUE swelling: The patient has swelling in his right upper extremity (RUE) due to a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein.
* UTI: The patient has a culture-positive UTI due to Pseudomonas, which is sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
* Seizure activity vs. myoclonus: The patient has had possible seizure activity, but the neurology team believes it is likely encephalopathy.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient has a culture-positive UTI and an infected dialysis line, which increases his risk of developing sepsis.
* Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status and possible seizure activity suggest encephalopathy, which could worsen his condition.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's labile blood pressures and cardiac arrest history increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure could worsen, leading to further complications.
* Wound infection: The patient's RUE swelling and infected dialysis line increase his risk of developing a wound infection.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's altered mental status and possible seizure activity suggest electrolyte imbalance, which could worsen his condition.

In summary, the patient is a high-risk individual who requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   - Continue with pressure support ventilation.  Will likely not be able
   to think of extubation until patient
s mental status improves.
   - Continue continuous dialysis to remove any excess fluid
   - Should do daily RSBI / SBT today
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  It has recently been difficult
   to assess his mental status because he is so agitated when we lighten
   sedation.  His MRI, though severely limited by motion artifact, did not
   show any signs of acute ischemia.  His EEG reads show possible seizure
   activity.
   - We will try to sedate him as much as possible with just propofol and
   small amounts of fentanyl; he is not tolerating the lowering of
   fentanyl well
   - repeat an exam this afternoon off of propofol
   - Continue to try Lidocaine oral spray to see if he can tolerate the
   ETT tube
   - F/u Neurology recs.
   - start  Keppra when off propofol
    .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   .
   # Fever: Patient
s fever curve is improving now with lines removed
   (some low grade fevers overnight)  Dialysis line is growing
   micrococcus.
   - ID believes cefepime will suffice for treatment.  As this was an
   infected line/bacteremia, we should cover with 14 days of adequate
   antibiotics.
   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid pending ID input.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF
   unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Restarted back on
   CVVH after getting new lines placed, yesterday many liters negative.
   Don't feel that we need to be as aggressive with fluid removal as he is
   about 14L negative through LOS.  Femoral dialysis port was replaced
   last night by IR
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Not clinically significant at this point.
   - Restart Calcitriol
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought to be unlikely. When pt had PICC placed yesterday
   found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile
   .
   #  UTI. Borderline UA. Culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2
   morphologies.  Sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
   - Continue Cefepime.  Has now completed 7d course but will continue due
   to persistent fevers.
   .
   # ?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus. Another 20 minute EEG was done this
   morning  Neuro has said that at this point it is likely encephalopathy.
   - f/u EEG results
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.

   - continue to monitor.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He developed respiratory failure and was intubated, and later suffered a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. The patient has been in the ICU for several days and has had multiple complications, including sepsis, ARF, and altered mental status.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on pressure support ventilation and is not tolerating extubation.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has labile blood pressures, with episodes of hypotension and hypertension.
* Neurological status: The patient has altered mental status, with possible seizure activity and encephalopathy.
* Renal status: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and is receiving continuous dialysis.
* Infectious status: The patient has a catheter-tip infection with Micrococcus species, and is receiving antibiotics.
* Nutritional status: The patient is receiving tube feeds and has a history of diabetes mellitus type II.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is declining, and he may require further ventilatory support.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's labile blood pressures may lead to further episodes of hypotension or hypertension.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, and he may require further sedation or neuromuscular blockade.
* Infectious complications: The patient's catheter-tip infection may spread to other sites, and he may develop further sepsis.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen, and he may require further dialysis or renal replacement therapy.

Plan:

* Continue pressure support ventilation and monitor for further respiratory deterioration.
* Manage labile blood pressures with fluid boluses and medications as needed.
* Continue antibiotics for the catheter-tip infection and monitor for further infectious complications.
* Monitor the patient's neurological status and consider further sedation or neuromuscular blockade as needed.
* Continue renal replacement therapy and monitor for further renal deterioration.
* Consider stress-dose steroids if the patient's HD is unstable.
* Monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust tube feeds as needed.
* Consider further imaging studies to evaluate for potential causes of ARF.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF).
* He has been intubated and ventilated due to respiratory failure and altered mental status.
* His blood pressure is labile, and he has intermittent hypotension and hypertension.
* He has a fever curve that is improving, and his lines have been removed.
* He has an infected dialysis line that is growing micrococcus, and he is being treated with cefepime and linezolid.
* He has a UTI with a positive culture for Pseudomonas, which is sensitive to zosyn and cefepime.
* He has anemia that is chronic and stable, and he is being monitored.
* He has type II diabetes that is well-controlled with sliding scale insulin.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is acute and may progress to chronic respiratory failure if not managed properly.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is end-stage, and he may require dialysis for the rest of his life.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and may be at risk for another arrest if not managed properly.
* Infection: The patient has an infected dialysis line and a UTI, which may lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure if not treated promptly and effectively.
* Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status and may be at risk for neurological complications such as seizures or encephalopathy.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased immune function.
* Hypoglycemia: The patient has a history of hypoglycemia and may be at risk for another episode if not managed properly.
* DVT: The patient has a history of DVT and may be at risk for another episode if not managed properly.

**Plan:**

* Continue ventilation and sedation as needed to manage respiratory failure.
* Continue dialysis and adjust as needed to manage renal failure.
* Monitor blood pressure and adjust as needed to manage labile blood pressure.
* Continue antibiotics to treat infected dialysis line and UTI.
* Monitor for signs of neurological complications and treat promptly if necessary.
* Monitor anemia and adjust treatment as needed.
* Monitor for signs of hypoglycemia and adjust treatment as needed.
* Monitor for signs of DVT and adjust treatment as needed.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now

   chest and has had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear
   whether he truly has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
   negative to date.
   - Continues mechanically ventilated due to mental status and it is
   unclear if his mental status will improve given that his off sedation
   exams have been less purposeful recently, after initial signs of
   progress and following commands.
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
   - Will have to start thinking about trach/PEG if family wants to
   continue support.
   - Will need to have repeat family meeting about goals of care, but will
   have to touch base with Neurology about his chances of recovery first,
   given most recent exams
   - Daily off sedation exams, RSBI
s, SBT
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  His MRI, though severely
   limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute ischemia.
   Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   - Had been trying to wean the Fentanyl and sedate more with Propofol,
   but has not tolerated this very well and still on substantial amts of
   Fentanyl
   - Continue to try Lidocaine oral spray to see if he can tolerate the
   ETT tube
   - Start  Keppra when off propofol
   - consider haldol instead of fentanyl in the future
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF
   unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and have been
   unsuccessful.
   - No need for urgent HD/CVVH per renal
   - Will need to go to IR on Monday for replacement of his line, then
   restart CVVH afterwards.
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with acute respiratory failure and cardiac arrest. He is currently mechanically ventilated due to altered mental status and respiratory failure. His medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and chronic kidney disease.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He is mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure, which is likely secondary to acute on chronic renal failure.
* Altered mental status: He is agitated and has not tolerated weaning from sedation, with a recent MRI showing no signs of acute ischemia.
* Renal failure: He has acute on chronic renal failure, with a recent renal biopsy showing severe chronic kidney disease.
* Hypotension: He has intermittent hypotension, which is likely due to hypovolemia or an infectious source.
* Fever: He has low-grade fevers, which are being treated with antibiotics.
* Hypocalcemia: He has hypocalcemia, which is likely secondary to renal failure.
* Hyperphosphatemia: He has hyperphosphatemia, which is likely secondary to renal failure.
* Electrolyte imbalance: He has an electrolyte imbalance, with hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia.
* Anemia: He has chronic and stable anemia, which may be related to renal disease.
* Seizure activity: He has had recent seizure activity, which may be related to encephalopathy or seizure activity.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he is not weaned from mechanical ventilation.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may worsen if he does not receive adequate dialysis.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if he does not receive adequate fluid resuscitation.
* Fever: The patient's fever may worsen if he does not receive adequate antibiotics.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance may worsen if he does not receive adequate electrolyte replacement.
* Seizure activity: The patient's seizure activity may worsen if he does not receive adequate anticonvulsant therapy.

Plan:

* Continue mechanical ventilation to support the patient's respiratory failure.
* Continue antibiotics to treat the patient's fever and pneumonia.
* Continue dialysis to manage the patient's renal failure.
* Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and replace as necessary.
* Monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust anticonvulsant therapy as necessary.
* Consider tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) if the patient's mental status does not improve.
* Consider stress dose prednisone if the patient's hypertension does not respond to labetalol.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old man who suffered an asystolic/PEA arrest while in the intensive care unit (ICU) to get a hemodialysis (HD) line. He has a history of renal failure in a renal transplant and fever. He has made remarkable improvements in his neurologic exam and has a good chance of significant recovery, but has been more delirious for the past few days.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Renal failure, end-stage (ESRD)
* Cardiac arrest
* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Fever
* Oral secretions
* Micrococcus line infection

The patient is currently receiving propofol and fentanyl infusions, and his mental status is limiting his ability to be extubated. The plan is to try adding Haldol 2-5mg IV to observe and decrease propofol. The patient will need discussion with neurology and then family to readdress his mental status and goals of care.

The patient's lab results show:

* Hemoglobin: 7.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 7.8-8.1 K/uL
* Platelet count: 286-283 K/uL
* Creatinine: 4.1-4.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 5.0-47 mg/dL
* Sodium: 134-131 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.1-4.8 mmol/L
* Chloride: 95-131 mmol/L
* Calcium: 11.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 5.1 mg/dL

The patient's imaging results show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR) unchanged
* Microbiology: micrococcus + catheter tip, no bacteremia

The patient's fluid analysis shows:

* Sodium: 134-131 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.1-4.8 mmol/L
* Chloride: 95-131 mmol/L
* Calcium: 11.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 5.1 mg/dL

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Renal failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Altered mental status
* Fever
* Oral secretions
* Micrococcus line infection
* Hyponatremia
* Hypovolemia
* Electrolyte imbalances

The patient's plan includes:

* Trying adding Haldol 2-5mg IV to observe and decrease propofol
* Discussing mental status and goals of care with neurology and family
* Readdressing mental status and goals of care
* Considering tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) if unable to liberate from ventilator
* Managing micrococcus line infection with linezolid and cefipime
* Monitoring and managing hyponatremia and electrolyte imbalances
* Reviewing and adjusting the patient's medication regimen as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old man who suffered an asystolic/PEA arrest while in the intensive care unit (ICU) to get a hemodialysis (HD) line. He has been intubated for 12 days and has been unresponsive except to noxious stimuli for the past few days. He has a history of acute renal failure (ARF) in a renal transplant, and his mental status has been improving until recently. He has been treated with propofol and fentanyl for sedation, but his mental status remains limited.

The patient's current condition includes:

* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Renal failure, end-stage (ESRD)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Cardiac arrest
* Micrococcus line infection

The patient's active issues include:

* Post-arrest (post-cooling)
* ARF in renal transplant
* Resp failure
* Mental status (now on propofol 30/fent 50)
* Oral secretions
* Micrococcus line infection

The plan includes:

1. Mental status/delirium/sedation: adding Haldol 2-5mg IV to observe if possible to decrease propofol.
2. ID: linezolid/cefipime for micrococcus line infection
3. Hyponatremia: trial small bolus NS. Recheck PM lytes for f/u Na, Ca
4. HD line: IR plans to fix line tomorrow

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and any further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
2. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is already compromised, and any further decline could lead to end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
3. Infection: The patient has a micrococcus line infection, which could lead to sepsis and further complications.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac arrest and subsequent cooling could lead to cardiovascular instability and arrhythmias.
5. Neurological damage: The patient's prolonged period of hypoxia and hypoperfusion could lead to neurological damage and long-term cognitive impairment.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's prolonged stay in the ICU could lead to gastrointestinal complications such as pressure ulcers, aspiration pneumonia, and malnutrition.
7. Psychosocial complications: The patient's prolonged stay in the ICU and his altered mental status could lead to psychosocial complications such as anxiety, depression, and delirium.

 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now vent dependent due to mental status.
   Active issues at this point:
   # Respiratory failure.  Back on pressure support this morning and
   tolerating well.  Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.
   - Continues mechanically ventilated due to mental status and it is
   unclear if his mental status will improve given that his off sedation
   exams have been less purposeful recently, after initial signs of
   progress and following commands.
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
   - Need to discuss trach/peg with family.
   - Daily off sedation exams, RSBI
s, SBT
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of 700.
   - Have had to change to fentanyl/versed because of very high
   triglycerides
   - Start  Keppra if having EEG
   - f/u neurology recs.
   - consider haldol instead of fentanyl in the future
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  Needs to have femoral HD line
   replaced today.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF unclear thus
   far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will regain enough
   renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back on CVVH after
   getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not been
   functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and have been
   unsuccessful.
   - Will need to go to IR today for replacement of his line, then restart
   CVVH afterwards.
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - stop calcitriol and increase aluminum hydroxide.
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   # Fever: continued low-grade temps.  Will continue cefepime and
   linezolid.  Pt still with some low grade fevers, has been on long
   course of Cefepime and most recently Linezolid added for past 6 days.
   These were initially treating UTI with Pseudomonas. Now, he has grown
   out Micrococcus from
 catheter tips from CVL
s that were pulled the
   other day. ID has said that Cefipime will suffice for this Micrococcus.
   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid for 14d course. Today is day 11 of
   Cefepime and day 7 of Linezolid
   - Would clarify the exact time course for these two ABx
 14d from when
   Micrococcus was isolated?
   # HypoNa: Today level is because of lipemia.  Possibly volume deplete
   as he is about 14L negative through LOS. Will give small 250cc bolus
   today and f/u electrolytes later today.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic.
   - F/u with renal about electrolytes
   Other stable issues:
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile
   #  UTI. Borderline UA. Culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2

   - Continue Cefepime.  Has now completed 10d course but will continue
   due to persistent fevers.
   # ?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus. Another 20 minute EEG was done this
   morning  Neuro has said that at this point it is likely encephalopathy,
   but may be some seizure activity.  Recommended starting Keppra when
   Propofol off
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated due to mental status and has been weaned off sedation, but his exams have been less purposeful recently.
* Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but has difficulty assessing his cortex. His MRI did not show any signs of acute ischemia.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure and requires femoral HD line replacement today. He is unlikely to regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient had a PEA arrest and is currently on pressure support.
* Fever: The patient has continued low-grade temperatures and is being treated with cefepime and linezolid.
* HypoNa: The patient's sodium levels are low due to lipemia, and he will receive a small 250cc bolus today.
* Endo: The patient has elevated PTH levels due to renal failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's mental status may not improve, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
2. Renal failure: The patient's renal function may not improve, and he may require continued dialysis.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient may experience another cardiac arrest if his cardiac condition is not managed properly.
4. Infection: The patient's fever and low-grade temperatures may indicate an underlying infection, which could worsen his condition.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's sodium levels are low, and he may require further electrolyte management.
6. Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status may be due to encephalopathy, which could worsen if not managed properly.
7. Seizure activity: The patient may experience seizure activity, which could worsen his condition if not managed properly.
8. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glucose levels may drop, which could worsen his condition if not managed properly.
9. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed properly.

To manage these potential complications, the patient's medical team should:

1. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with dialysis and medication.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust his medication as needed.
4. Investigate the patient's fever and low-grade temperatures to determine the underlying cause.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and adjust his medication as needed.
6. Continue to manage the patient's encephalopathy with medication and close monitoring.
7. Monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust his medication as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's glucose levels closely and adjust his medication as needed.
9. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with medication and close monitoring.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now vent dependent due to mental status.
   Active issues at this point:
   # Respiratory failure.  He was originally intubated in setting of
   arrest with possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT
   chest and has had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear
   whether he truly has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
   negative to date.
   - Continues mechanically ventilated due to mental status and it is
   unclear if his mental status will improve given that his off sedation
   exams have been less purposeful recently, after initial signs of
   progress and following commands.
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
   - Will have to start thinking about trach/PEG if family wants to
   continue support.
   - Will need to have repeat family meeting about goals of care, but will
   have to touch base with Neurology about his chances of recovery first,
   given most recent exams
   - Daily off sedation exams, RSBI
s, SBT
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  His MRI, though severely
   limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute ischemia.
   Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   - Had been trying to wean the Fentanyl and sedate more with Propofol,
   but has not tolerated this very well and still on substantial amts of
   Fentanyl
   - Continue to try Lidocaine oral spray to see if he can tolerate the
   ETT tube
   - Start  Keppra when off propofol
   - consider haldol instead of fentanyl in the future
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF
   unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and have been
   unsuccessful.
   - No need for urgent HD/CVVH per renal
   - Will need to go to IR on Monday for replacement of his line, then
   restart CVVH afterwards.
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   # Fever: Pt still with some low grade fevers, has been on long course
   of Cefepime and most recently Linezolid added for past 6 days. These
   were initially treating UTI with Pseudomonas. Now, he has grown out
   Micrococcus from
 catheter tips from CVL
s that were pulled the other

   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid for 14d course. Today is day 11 of

   - Would clarify the exact time course for these two ABx
 14d from when

   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who suffered a cardiac arrest and is currently ventilator-dependent due to altered mental status. He has a history of chronic renal failure, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient's current issues include respiratory failure, altered mental status, renal failure, and labile blood pressures. He is also experiencing diarrhea, which has been treated with C. diff testing.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is currently mechanically ventilated. Weaning from the ventilator may be challenging due to his altered mental status and copious secretions.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is altered, and he is currently receiving sedation. Weaning from sedation may be challenging, and he may require long-term mental status support.
3. Renal Failure: The patient has end-stage renal disease and is currently undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). His renal function is likely to remain unstable, and he may require long-term dialysis.
4. Labile Blood Pressures: The patient's blood pressures are labile, and he is at risk for hypotension or hypertension. Tight control of his blood pressure is essential to prevent complications.
5. Fever: The patient has a low-grade fever, which may be related to his underlying infections or other causes. Close monitoring of his temperature and treatment of any underlying infections are essential.
6. HypoNa: The patient is hypoNaemic, which may be related to his volume depletion or other causes. Close monitoring of his electrolytes and treatment of any underlying causes are essential.
7. Endocrine Abnormalities: The patient has elevated PTH levels, which are likely secondary to his renal failure. Close monitoring of his electrolytes and treatment of any underlying causes are essential.
8. Seizure Activity: The patient may be experiencing seizure activity, which may be related to his encephalopathy or other causes. Close monitoring of his seizure activity and treatment of any underlying causes are essential.
9. UTI: The patient has a UTI, which may be related to his indwelling catheter or other causes. Close monitoring of his urine output and treatment of any underlying infections are essential.
10. Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia, which may be related to his renal disease or other causes. Close monitoring of his hemoglobin levels and treatment of any underlying causes are essential.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, neurological, and endocrine status.

 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now vent dependent due to mental status.
   Active issues at this point:
   # Respiratory failure.  Back on pressure support this morning.
   He was originally intubated in setting of arrest with possible hypoxia
   beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has had CXR's with
   LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly has PNA or
   not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to date.
   - Continues mechanically ventilated due to mental status and it is
   unclear if his mental status will improve given that his off sedation
   exams have been less purposeful recently, after initial signs of
   progress and following commands.
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
   - Will have to start thinking about trach/PEG if family wants to
   continue support.
   - Will need to have repeat family meeting about goals of care, but will
   have to touch base with Neurology about his chances of recovery first,
   given most recent exams
   - Daily off sedation exams, RSBI
s, SBT
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
    Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of 700.
   - Had been trying to wean the Fentanyl and sedate more with Propofol,
   but has not tolerated this very well and still on substantial amts of
   Fentanyl
   - Continue to try Lidocaine oral spray to see if he can tolerate the
   ETT tube
   - Start  Keppra when off propofol
   - consider haldol instead of fentanyl in the future
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF
   unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and have been
   unsuccessful.
   - No need for urgent HD/CVVH per renal
   - Will need to go to IR on Monday for replacement of his line, then
   restart CVVH afterwards.
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   # Fever: continued low-grade temps.  Will continue cefepime and
   linezolid.
   Pt still with some low grade fevers, has been on long course of
   Cefepime and most recently Linezolid added for past 6 days. These were
   initially treating UTI with Pseudomonas. Now, he has grown out
   Micrococcus from
 catheter tips from CVL
s that were pulled the other
   day. ID has said that Cefipime will suffice for this Micrococcus.
   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid for 14d course. Today is day 11 of
   Cefepime and day 7 of Linezolid
   - Would clarify the exact time course for these two ABx
 14d from when
   Micrococcus was isolated?
   # HypoNa: Possibly volume deplete as he is about 14L negative through
   LOS. Will give small 250cc bolus today and f/u electrolytes later
   today.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic.
   - F/u with renal about electrolytes
   Other stable issues:
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile
   #  UTI. Borderline UA. Culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2
   morphologies.  Sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
   - Continue Cefepime.  Has now completed 10d course but will continue
   due to persistent fevers.
   # ?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus. Another 20 minute EEG was done this
   morning  Neuro has said that at this point it is likely encephalopathy,
   but may be some seizure activity.  Recommended starting Keppra when
   Propofol off
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease
   - continue to monitor.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line, R PICC placed [**11-23**], and R fem HD line with VIP
   port placed [**11-23**]
 will need to have R fem HD line replaced

He has a history of chronic renal failure and was previously on continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). He has been diagnosed with acute on chronic renal failure and is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

4. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is altered, and it is unclear if he will improve given his recent exams.

6. HypoNa: The patient has a negative sodium balance, and there is concern about the need for further electrolyte replacement.
7. Endocrine: The patient has elevated PTH levels, which are likely secondary or tertiary to his renal failure.
8. UTI: The patient has a UTI, and there is concern about the need for further antibiotic treatment.
9. Seizure activity: The patient has had seizure-like activity, and there is concern about the need for further seizure treatment.
10. Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia, and there is concern about the need for further iron replacement.

Labs and Imaging:

Patient's Condition:

* The patient is a 61-year-old man with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with worsening chronic renal failure (CRF).
* He had a cardiac arrest in the intensive care unit (ICU) with attempted placement of a hemodialysis (HD) line, which was clogged and not working.
* The patient has been experiencing high triglycerides, diarrhea, and fevers.
* He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
* The patient has altered mental status, which has worsened, and is likely experiencing delirium due to medications and renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is already experiencing respiratory failure, and the risk of further deterioration is high. The need for tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) is imminent.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient has already experienced a cardiac arrest, and the risk of recurrent arrest is high due to his underlying cardiac disease and renal failure.
* Sepsis: The patient has fevers and is at risk of developing sepsis, particularly due to the clogged HD line and the presence of micrococcus.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has diarrhea and is at risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly due to his altered mental status and the use of anticoagulant medications.
* Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, particularly due to his immunocompromised state and the presence of a catheter.
* Renal failure: The patient is already experiencing end-stage renal disease, and the risk of further deterioration is high.
* Cardiovascular disease: The patient has underlying cardiac disease, and the risk of further cardiac complications is high.
* Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status, which can progress to coma or death.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now

    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Has been on AC for most of MICU course, but yesterday tried on
   pressure support and tolerating well.
   - At this point, most importantly need to speak with family and discuss
   trach/PEG and moving towards rehab as he doesn
t appear to be making
   great strides in terms of his mental status or his respiratory status.
   - His agitation could be in part due to the ETT and it
s reasonable to
   to think getting it out could be beneficial
 Trach talk with family
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700.
   - Neuro has been following and they have put him back on continuous EEG
   due to a staring spell that they witnessed yesterday
   - Start  Keppra if having EEG changes
   - Will give a trial of Haldol today to see if any improvement.
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and have been
   unsuccessful. Needs to have femoral HD line replaced today.
   - Will need to go to IR today for replacement of his line, then restart
   CVVH afterwards.
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - stop calcitriol and increase aluminum hydroxide per renal recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: continued low-grade temps.  Will continue cefepime and
   linezolid.  Pt still with some low grade fevers, has been on long
   course of Cefepime and most recently Linezolid added for past 6 days.
   These were initially treating UTI with Pseudomonas. Now, he has grown
   out Micrococcus from
 catheter tips from CVL
s that were pulled the
   other day. ID has said that Cefipime will suffice for this Micrococcus.
   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid for 14d course. Today is day 12 of
   Cefepime and day 8 of Linezolid
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen but unclear if this will only be with HD/CVVH
   - continue to monitor.
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   # HypoNa: Normal today but recently low. Thought to be lipemic samples
   vs  possibly volume deplete as he is about 14L negative through LOS.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   - F/u with renal about electrolytes
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile
   #  UTI. Borderline UA. Culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2
   morphologies.  Sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
   - Continue Cefepime.  Has now completed 10d course but will continue
   due to persistent fevers as above

   monitoring did not show outright seizure activity but
epileptiform
   activity
 according to Neuro. He was not ever started on AED

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with acute respiratory failure (ARF) and cardiac arrest. He is currently mechanically ventilated and has a tracheostomy tube in place. His mental status is altered, and he is not responsive to external stimuli. He has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated creatinine and urea levels, indicating chronic kidney disease
* Elevated potassium and phosphorus levels, indicating electrolyte imbalance
* Elevated liver enzymes, indicating liver dysfunction
* Low albumin and protein levels, indicating malnutrition
* Elevated blood glucose levels, indicating hyperglycemia
* Elevated white blood cell count, indicating infection

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: Clear lungs, with some interval improvement in right upper lobe opacity
* CT chest: No evidence of pneumonia or pleural effusion

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Acute on chronic renal failure
* Respiratory failure
* Altered mental status
* Fever
* Anemia
* Labile blood pressures
* HypoNa
* End-stage renal disease
* HypoNa
* UTI
*?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus
* DM type II

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis
* ARDS
* Pneumonia
* Pleural effusion
* Pulmonary embolism
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Hypertensive crisis
* Hypoglycemia
* Hyperkalemia
* Hyperphosphatemia
* Hypercalcemia
* Renal failure
* Liver failure
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiovascular collapse

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation
* Wean sedation and try to extubate the patient
* Start Keppra for seizure activity
* Continue Cefepime and Linezolid for UTI
* Start Epogen for anemia
* Continue to monitor electrolytes and adjust therapy as needed
* Discuss PEG placement with family
* Consider moving to vent rehab if trach and PEG are placed

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with a complex medical history, including end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus (DM) type II. He was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and altered mental status.

Current Issues:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated due to mental status and unclear if his mental status will improve given that his off-sedation exams have been less purposeful recently.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but has difficulty assessing his cortex. He has had MRI, which did not show any signs of acute ischemia. Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient needs to have his femoral HD line replaced today. He is s/p CRT and has unclear etiology of ARF, but it is unlikely that he will regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.
4. Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, and it is unclear if it is related to renal disease or ACD. He is to start Epogen but unclear if it will only be with HD/CVVH.
5. Labile blood pressures: The patient has intermittent hypotension due to hypovolemia or infectious source, and hypertension for which he was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG.
6. Fever: The patient has continued low-grade temps and is being treated with Cefepime and Linezolid.
7. HypoNa: The patient has a low sodium level due to lipemia, and possibly volume depletion as he is about 14L negative through LOS.
8. Endocrine: The patient has elevated PTH, which is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal failure. He has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic.
9. UTI: The patient has a borderline UA culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2 morphologies, sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
10.?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus: The patient has had 20-minute EEG, and it is likely encephalopathy, but may be some seizure activity.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to his underlying chronic lung disease and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to his UTI and fever.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is at risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Renal failure: The patient is at risk of developing acute renal failure due to his underlying chronic kidney disease and acute kidney injury.
5. Anemia: The patient is at risk of developing anemia due to his chronic kidney disease and potential bleeding.
6. HypoNa: The patient is at risk of developing hypovolemic shock due to his low sodium level and volume depletion.
7. Endocrine: The patient is at risk of developing hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia due to his underlying chronic kidney disease and potential parathyroid hormone (PTH) imbalance.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and sedation as needed to manage respiratory failure.
2. Continue antibiotics for UTI and fever.
3. Replace femoral HD line and restart CVVH as soon as possible.
4. Monitor patient's mental status and adjust sedation and antibiotics as needed.
5. Continue to monitor patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment as needed.
6. Consider stress dose prednisone if HD is unstable.
7. Continue to monitor patient's blood pressure and adjust treatment as needed.
8. Consider starting Keppra if patient is having seizure activity or myoclonus.
9. Continue to monitor patient's glucose levels and adjust treatment as needed.
10. Consider starting stress dose corticosteroids if patient is at risk of developing adrenal insufficiency.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who suffered a cardiac arrest and is currently in respiratory failure. He has a failed renal transplant and is on hemodialysis (HD). The patient has a tracheostomy tube in place and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He is agitated and requires sedation to allow him to breathe. His mental status is altered, and he is not following simple commands. The patient has a history of diarrhea, and his laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his agitated state and the need for increased sedation. This could lead to further respiratory acidosis and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and LDH levels suggest the possibility of sepsis. This could lead to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and failed renal transplant make him prone to further renal failure. This could lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and history of cardiovascular disease make him prone to further cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiogenic shock.
5. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and diarrhea suggest the possibility of infection. This could lead to further complications, such as sepsis, organ dysfunction, or potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's poor nutritional status, as evidenced by his low albumin levels, makes him prone to malnutrition and related complications, such as weakness, fatigue, and impaired wound healing.
7. Pressure Ulcers: The patient's immobility and poor nutritional status make him prone to pressure ulcers, which could lead to further complications, such as infection, sepsis, or potentially life-threatening complications.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's diarrhea and altered mental status suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
9. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status and poor nutritional status make him prone to neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, or potentially life-threatening complications.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications. The patient's respiratory failure, altered mental status, and poor nutritional status make him prone to a range of potential complications, including respiratory failure, sepsis, renal failure, cardiovascular complications, infection, malnutrition, pressure ulcers, gastrointestinal complications, and neurological complications.

 HYPERTENSION, BENIGN

 RENAL FAILURE, END STAGE (END STAGE RENAL DISEASE, ESRD)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now vent dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Has been on AC for most of MICU course, but yesterday tried on
   pressure support and tolerating well.
   - At this point, most importantly need to speak with family and discuss
   trach/PEG and moving towards rehab as he doesn
t appear to be making
   great strides in terms of his mental status or his respiratory status.
   - His agitation could be in part due to the ETT and it
s reasonable to
   to think getting it out could be beneficial
 Trach talk with family
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700.
   - Neuro has been following and they have put him back on continuous EEG
   due to a staring spell that they witnessed yesterday
   - Start  Keppra if having EEG changes
   - Will give a trial of Haldol today to see if any improvement.
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and have been
   unsuccessful. Needs to have femoral HD line replaced today.
   - Will need to go to IR today for replacement of his line, then restart
   CVVH afterwards.
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - stop calcitriol and increase aluminum hydroxide per renal recs
   - Renal is following

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who has been admitted to the ICU with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a history of chronic renal failure, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus (DM) type II.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He is ventilator-dependent due to acute respiratory failure, which was precipitated by a cardiac arrest. He has been intubated for most of his MICU course and has been on pressure support and tolerating it well.
* Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but has been agitated and unresponsive to commands, with no clear signs of acute ischemia on his MRI.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: He has been on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) but has not been functioning well, and his femoral HD line needs to be replaced today.
* Fever: He has been on a long course of cefepime and linezolid for a suspected urinary tract infection (UTI) with Pseudomonas, but now has grown Micrococcus from catheter tips.
* Anemia: He has chronic and stable anemia, which may be related to renal disease or ACD (c/w recent Fe studies).
* Labile blood pressures: He has intermittent hypotension due to hypovolemia or infectious source, and hypertension for which he was receiving labetalol.
* HypoNa: His sodium levels have been low, which may be due to lipemic samples or volume depletion.
* Endo: He has elevated PTH levels, which are likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal failure.
* RUE swelling: He has thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with +collaterals, which needs to be addressed prior to PICC removal.
* UTI: He has a borderline UA and culture-positive for Pseudomonas of two morphologies, which is sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
*?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus: He has had some epileptiform activity on his EEG, which may be related to encephalopathy or seizure activity.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: Prolonged mechanical ventilation can lead to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), respiratory muscle weakness, and decreased lung function.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's agitation and unresponsiveness can lead to further deterioration in his mental status, increased risk of aspiration, and decreased ability to communicate effectively.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's ongoing renal failure can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and further decline in his overall health.
4. Fever: The patient's persistent fevers can lead to sepsis, multi-organ dysfunction, and increased risk of mortality.
5. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, increased risk of infections, and decreased response to stress.
6. Labile blood pressures: The patient's intermittent hypotension and hypertension can lead to decreased organ perfusion, increased risk of cardiac arrest, and decreased ability to respond to stress.
7. HypoNa: The patient's low sodium levels can lead to decreased blood volume, decreased organ perfusion, and increased risk of seizures.
8. Endo: The patient's elevated PTH levels can lead to hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and further decline in his overall health.
9. RUE swelling: The patient's thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein can lead to decreased venous return, increased risk of DVT, and decreased ability to respond to stress.
10. UTI: The patient's UTI can lead to sepsis, multi-organ dysfunction, and increased risk of mortality.

In order to manage these potential complications, the patient will need to be closely monitored and treated with a multidisciplinary approach. This may include adjusting his medications, managing his fluid and electrolyte balance, and providing supportive care to address his respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal dysfunction.

   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700.

   unsuccessful. Needs to have femoral HD line replaced today.

   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In

   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He suffered a cardiac arrest and was intubated. He has been on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and has had multiple lines placed, including a dialysis catheter, PICC line, and femoral HD line. He has also had a tracheostomy tube placed. His current issues include:

* Respiratory failure: He is on a ventilator due to his ARF and has had difficulty weaning from sedation.
* Altered mental status: He has been agitated and has not been following commands or tracking.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: He has had difficulty with his dialysis catheter and has been on CVVH, but it has not been functioning well.
* Fever: He has had a low-grade fever and has been on antibiotics for a UTI.
* Anemia: He has chronic anemia and is being treated with Epogen.
* Labile blood pressures: He has had intermittent hypotension and hypertension.
* HypoNa: He has had low sodium levels and is being monitored.
* Endo: He has elevated PTH and is being treated with calcium and phosphorus supplements.
* RUE swelling: He has had swelling in his right upper extremity due to a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein.
* UTI: He has had a UTI and is being treated with antibiotics.
*?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus: He has had some seizure-like activity on his EEG, but it is unclear if it is due to seizure activity or encephalopathy.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: He may continue to have difficulty weaning from sedation and may require further interventions to improve his respiratory status.
* Altered mental status: He may continue to be agitated and may require further interventions to improve his mental status.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: He may continue to have difficulty with his dialysis catheter and may require further interventions to improve his renal function.
* Fever: He may continue to have a low-grade fever and may require further antibiotics to treat his UTI.
* Anemia: He may require further treatment with Epogen to improve his anemia.
* Labile blood pressures: He may continue to have intermittent hypotension and hypertension and may require further interventions to improve his blood pressure control.
* HypoNa: He may continue to have low sodium levels and may require further interventions to improve his sodium levels.
* Endo: He may continue to have elevated PTH and may require further treatment with calcium and phosphorus supplements.
* RUE swelling: He may continue to have swelling in his right upper extremity and may require further interventions to improve his circulation.
* UTI: He may continue to have a UTI and may require further antibiotics to treat the infection.
*?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus: He may continue to have seizure-like activity and may require further interventions to improve his seizure control.

   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will continue today with schedule Haldol to see if any improvement in
   his mental status
 5mg PO tid
   - If no response to Haldol, consider Seroquel
   - Get baseline EKG for Haldol
   - Continue Fent/Versed for sedation for now
