   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and have been
   unsuccessful.
   - He is scheduled to go to IR today for placement of a subclavian HD
   line
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. Today is day 14 of the Cefepime and day 9 of Linezolid.
   - We will stop ABx at this point, as he has gotten a long course of
   Cefepime and Linezolid.
   - Watch fever curve
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - His Hct is acutely down this am, will consider transfusing him
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and if he
   is hypertense through the day we will restart the Labetalol either prn
   or scheduled, as necessary. If hypotension returns, would give small
   boluses of fluid
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Normal today but recently low. Thought to be lipemic samples
   vs  possibly volume deplete as he is about 14L negative through LOS.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal

   - F/u with renal about electrolytes

   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.

epileptiform

 according to Neuro. He was not ever started on AED

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and Acute Respiratory Failure (ARF). He has a history of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD), Hypertension, and Diabetes Mellitus (DM). He suffered a cardiac arrest and was intubated. He has been receiving dialysis and has a tunneled hemodialysis catheter placed. His current condition is complicated by:

1. Respiratory failure: He is ventilator-dependent due to agitation and copious secretions.
2. Altered mental status: He has intact brainstem reflexes but is agitated and non-responsive to commands.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: He has ESRD and is unlikely to regain sufficient renal function to be free of dialysis.
4. Fever: He has had a long course of antibiotics for a positive urine culture and has been growing a microorganism in his central venous line (CVL).
5. Anemia: He has chronic and stable anemia, possibly related to renal disease.
6. Labile blood pressures: He has been intermittently hypotensive and hypertensive, requiring medication to manage his blood pressure.
7. Endocrine disorders: He has hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia due to renal failure.
8. RUE swelling: He has swelling in his right upper extremity (RUE) due to a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein.
9.?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus: He has had epileptiform activity on continuous EEG monitoring, which may be related to encephalopathy or seizure activity.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: Weaning from the ventilator may be challenging due to his agitation and copious secretions.
2. Altered mental status: His agitation and non-responsiveness to commands may indicate a need for further evaluation and management.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: His renal function may worsen, requiring further dialysis or consideration of renal replacement therapy.
4. Fever: His fever may persist or worsen, requiring further antibiotic therapy or evaluation for other causes.
5. Anemia: His anemia may worsen, requiring further evaluation and management.
6. Labile blood pressures: His blood pressure may continue to fluctuate, requiring further medication and management.
7. Endocrine disorders: His hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia may worsen, requiring further evaluation and management.
8. RUE swelling: His RUE swelling may persist or worsen, requiring further evaluation and management.
9.?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus: His epileptiform activity may persist or worsen, requiring further evaluation and management.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor his respiratory status and consider weaning from the ventilator when his agitation and secretions are controlled.
2. Continue to evaluate and manage his altered mental status, including further EEG monitoring and consideration of anticonvulsant therapy.
3. Continue to manage his acute on chronic renal failure, including further dialysis and consideration of renal replacement therapy.
4. Continue to monitor his fever and consider further antibiotic therapy or evaluation for other causes.
5. Continue to evaluate and manage his anemia, including further transfusions and consideration of erythropoietin therapy.
6. Continue to manage his labile blood pressures, including further medication and consideration of stress dose corticosteroids.
7. Continue to evaluate and manage his endocrine disorders, including further evaluation of his hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.
8. Continue to evaluate and manage his RUE swelling, including further evaluation of his brachial-cephalic vein.
9. Continue to evaluate and manage his?seizure activity vs. myoclonus, including further EEG monitoring and consideration of anticonvulsant therapy.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) who was admitted to the ICU with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a cardiac arrest and was intubated. The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, altered mental status, and acute on chronic renal failure. He has been on dialysis and has had multiple lines placed, including a dialysis catheter and a femoral HD line. The patient has also been experiencing fever, anemia, labile blood pressures, hypoNa, and elevated PTH.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and weaning him from the ventilator is challenging due to his agitation and copious secretions.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is a concern, and we are trying to determine the underlying cause. He has had a staring spell and has been experiencing agitation, which may be related to seizures or encephalopathy.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's renal function is severely impaired, and he is likely to require ongoing dialysis. We need to monitor his electrolytes and adjust his medications accordingly.
4. Fever: The patient's fever is a concern, and we need to continue to monitor his temperature and adjust his antibiotics as necessary.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is a concern, and we need to monitor his hemoglobin levels and adjust his medications accordingly.
6. Labile blood pressures: The patient's labile blood pressures are a concern, and we need to monitor his blood pressure and adjust his medications accordingly.
7. HypoNa: The patient's hypoNa is a concern, and we need to monitor his sodium levels and adjust his medications accordingly.
8. Endo: The patient's elevated PTH is a concern, and we need to monitor his electrolytes and adjust his medications accordingly.
9. RUE swelling: The patient's RUE swelling is a concern, and we need to monitor his swelling and adjust his medications accordingly.
10. UTI: The patient's UTI is a concern, and we need to continue to monitor his urine output and adjust his antibiotics as necessary.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his medications accordingly.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his dialysis settings as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's fever and adjust his antibiotics as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust his medications accordingly.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's labile blood pressures and adjust his medications accordingly.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hypoNa and adjust his medications accordingly.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's endo and adjust his medications accordingly.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's RUE swelling and adjust his medications accordingly.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's UTI and adjust his antibiotics as necessary.

Next Steps:

1. We will continue to monitor the patient's status and adjust his medications as necessary.
2. We will continue to discuss the patient's treatment plan with his family and adjust his care accordingly.
3. We will continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
4. We will continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his medications accordingly.
5. We will continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his dialysis settings as necessary.
6. We will continue to monitor the patient's fever and adjust his antibiotics as necessary.
7. We will continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust his medications accordingly.
8. We will continue to monitor the patient's labile blood pressures and adjust his medications accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old man with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), who suffered a cardiac arrest and is currently in respiratory failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, blood pressure of 145/71 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He has a fever of 37.7Â°C (99.8Â°F) and is receiving antibiotics for suspected sepsis.

The patient's medical history includes hypertension, benign, and ESRD on HD. He has also had a cardiac arrest and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN), indicating renal failure. His electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with elevated potassium and phosphorus.

The patient's current medications include Keppra for seizures, Haldol for agitation, and antibiotics for suspected sepsis. He is also receiving prophylactic antibiotics for DVT and stress ulcer prevention.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and the possibility of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) cannot be ruled out.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and laboratory results suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death.
3. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD on HD is a significant concern, and the possibility of acute kidney injury (AKI) cannot be ruled out.
4. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest increases the risk of future cardiac events, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and seizure activity increase the risk of neurological complications, including stroke and seizures.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea and altered mental status increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, including bowel obstruction and perforation.
7. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and presence of indwelling catheters increase the risk of infection, including central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) and catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI).

 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Will continue today with schedule Haldol to see if any improvement in
   his mental status 5mg PO tid
   - Seroquel was also tried last night, but unsure if either the Haldol
   or the Seroquel, or increasing the Versed, has made much difference
   - F/u EKG for Haldol/Seroquel
   - Get baseline EKG for Haldol
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Had considered transfusing yesterday, will give him 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line, R PICC placed [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line
   placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.

 HYPERTENSION, BENIGN
 DIARRHEA

 RENAL FAILURE, END STAGE (END STAGE RENAL DISEASE, ESRD)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Will continue today with schedule Haldol to see if any improvement in
   his mental status 5mg PO tid
   - Seroquel was also tried last night, but unsure if either the Haldol
   or the Seroquel, or increasing the Versed, has made much difference
   - F/u EKG for Haldol/Seroquel
   - Get baseline EKG for Haldol
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Had considered transfusing yesterday, will give him 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line, R PICC placed [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line
   placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a history of cardiac arrest, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease. He is currently ventilator-dependent due to altered mental status and respiratory failure. The patient has been experiencing hypertension, which is resistant to labetalol, and has been treated with various medications including fentanyl, midazolam, and haloperidol. He has also been experiencing copious secretions, which is concerning for aspiration.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to his underlying ARF, which has led to decreased lung function and increased risk of respiratory complications.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to his underlying ESRD, which has led to decreased cognitive function and increased risk of delirium.
3. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is likely due to his underlying ESRD, which has led to increased blood pressure and decreased renal function.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely due to his underlying ESRD, which has led to decreased kidney function and increased risk of complications.
5. Infection: The patient's recent fever and positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Cardiac arrest: The patient's recent cardiac arrest suggests the possibility of underlying cardiac disease, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's recent gastrointestinal bleeding suggests the possibility of underlying gastrointestinal disease, which could lead to further complications.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's recent neurological symptoms, including seizures and altered mental status, suggest the possibility of underlying neurological disease, which could lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his sedation and analgesia as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust his antihypertensive medications as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his dialysis settings as needed.
5. Consider the possibility of underlying infection and order additional diagnostic tests as needed.
6. Consider the possibility of underlying cardiac disease and order additional diagnostic tests as needed.
7. Consider the possibility of underlying gastrointestinal disease and order additional diagnostic tests as needed.
8. Consider the possibility of underlying neurological disease and order additional diagnostic tests as needed.

Action Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his sedation and analgesia as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust his antihypertensive medications as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his dialysis settings as needed.
5. Order additional diagnostic tests as needed to evaluate the patient's underlying condition.
6. Consider the possibility of underlying infection and order additional diagnostic tests as needed.
7. Consider the possibility of underlying cardiac disease and order additional diagnostic tests as needed.
8. Consider the possibility of underlying gastrointestinal disease and order additional diagnostic tests as needed.
9. Consider the possibility of underlying neurological disease and order additional diagnostic tests as needed.

 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now vent dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Will continue today with schedule Haldol to see if any improvement in
   his mental status 5mg PO tid
   - Seroquel was also tried last night, but unsure if either the Haldol
   or the Seroquel, or increasing the Versed, has made much difference
   - F/u EKG for Haldol/Seroquel
   - Get baseline EKG for Haldol
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Had considered transfusing yesterday, will give him 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line, R PICC placed [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line
   placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and Acute Renal Failure (ARF). He suffered a Cardiac Arrest and was intubated. The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, altered mental status, and labile blood pressures.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Vent-dependent due to mental status; copious secretions are concerning for aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent.
* Neurological: Altered mental status with agitation, staring spells, and fasiculations in bilateral temporal areas, concerning for electrical discharge in facial nerve.
* Cardiovascular: Hypertension, benign; labile blood pressures, intermittently hypotensive and hypertensive.
* Renal: Acute on chronic renal failure; ESRD; on CVVH; calcium levels will improve with CVVH.
* Infectious: Fever, low-grade; previously had positive UCx with Pseudomonas; currently off antibiotics.
* Endocrine: Anemia, chronic and stable; B12 and Folate normal.
* Gastrointestinal: Diarrhea; previously had hypoglycemia, now well-controlled with sliding scale insulin.
* Other: Distended abdomen, no bleeding, no evidence of bowel obstruction.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Continued weaning from the vent may be challenging due to the patient's agitation and copious secretions.
* Neurological: The patient's altered mental status and fasiculations in bilateral temporal areas may indicate ongoing seizures or electrical discharge in facial nerve, which requires further evaluation and management.
* Cardiovascular: Labile blood pressures may lead to hypotension or hypertension, which can worsen the patient's condition.
* Renal: Acute on chronic renal failure may require continued CVVH and close monitoring of electrolyte levels.
* Infectious: The patient's fever and previous positive UCx with Pseudomonas may indicate ongoing infection, which requires close monitoring and potential antibiotic therapy.
* Endocrine: The patient's anemia may require further evaluation and management, including potential transfusions.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient's diarrhea may indicate ongoing gastrointestinal issues, which require further evaluation and management.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Coordination with IP and family for tracheostomy and PEG placement
* Continue CVVH and close monitoring of electrolyte levels
* Continue off antibiotics for now, watching fever curve
* Start Epogen with HD
* Start Keppra 250mg IV q12 for seizure prophylaxis
* Uptitrate Versed gtt as needed
* Continue Haldol 5mg PO tid for agitation
* Get baseline EKG for Haldol
* F/u EKG for Haldol/Seroquel
* Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD unstable
* Continue to watch lytes qday
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed
* Consider stress dose prednisone if HD unstable
* Discuss PEG placement with family
* Consider moving to vent rehab if trach and PEG placed.

 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available; need consent for procedures
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Increase haldol to 10mg tid
   - F/u EKG done today because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line
 need new art line placed today, R PICC placed

   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a cardiac arrest and was intubated. He has been experiencing hypertension, diarrhea, and altered mental status (AMS). He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been having trouble weaning due to agitation and copious secretions.

The patient's recent events include:

* Placement of a dialysis catheter in the left subclavian vein
* Restart of continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH)
* Stopping of Cefepime and Linezolid antibiotics
* Addition of Seroquel for agitation
* Increase in Haldol dosage
* Increase in Versed infusion
* Placement of a left subclavian line for HD
* Restart of CVVH
* Increase in aluminum hydroxide dosage
* Stopping of calcitriol
* Addition of Keppra for seizure prophylaxis

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's agitation and copious secretions make it difficult to wean him from the ventilator.
* Altered mental status: The patient's AMS is a concern, and it is unclear whether it is related to his cardiac arrest or other underlying conditions.
* Renal failure: The patient's ESRD is likely to continue, and he may require ongoing dialysis.
* Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is a concern, and it may be related to his renal failure or other underlying conditions.
* Infection: The patient's fever and positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of an infection.
* Seizure activity: The patient's recent episode of staring spell and epileptiform spikes on EEG suggest the possibility of seizure activity.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider tracheostomy and PEG placement if possible.
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and consider neuroimaging studies if necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dialysis as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider antihypertensive medications if necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and consider antibiotic therapy if necessary.
* Consider Keppra for seizure prophylaxis and adjust dosage as necessary.
* Consider increasing Versed infusion to help manage agitation.
* Consider increasing Haldol dosage to help manage agitation.
* Consider adding a second antihypertensive medication if necessary.
* Consider adding a diuretic medication if necessary to help manage hypertension.
* Consider adding a medication to help manage AMS if necessary.

 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available; need consent for procedures
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Increase haldol to 10mg tid
   - F/u EKG done today because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line
 need new art line placed today, R PICC placed
   [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with acute respiratory failure (ARF) and is currently ventilator-dependent. He has a complex medical history, including hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and cardiac arrest.

The patient's current conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: He is on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure, which is a major hindrance to weaning from the ventilator. The main issue is his agitation, which could be due to his endotracheal tube (ETT) and is a concern for aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has had a prolonged period of altered mental status (AMS) since his cardiac arrest, which is a concern for continued seizures. He has been on continuous EEG monitoring, which has shown epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. He is currently on Keppra and Versed, and his mental status is being closely monitored.
3. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, which is unlikely to improve significantly. He is currently on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) and will continue to require dialysis.
4. Fever: The patient has had a low-grade fever, which has been treated with antibiotics. He is currently off antibiotics and is being monitored for fever.
5. Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia, which is likely related to his renal disease. He is being treated with Epogen and will receive a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) today.
6. Labile blood pressures: The patient has been experiencing labile blood pressures, which are being managed with Labetalol.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: Weaning from the ventilator may be challenging due to the patient's agitation and risk of aspiration.
2. Seizures: The patient's altered mental status and history of cardiac arrest make him at risk for continued seizures, which could be life-threatening.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure is unlikely to improve significantly, and he will require ongoing dialysis.
4. Hypertension: The patient's labile blood pressures could lead to complications such as hypertensive encephalopathy or cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Infection: The patient's fever and history of antibiotic use make him at risk for developing an infection, which could be life-threatening.
6. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and history of cardiac arrest make him at risk for bleeding, which could be life-threatening.

In terms of the patient's plan of care, the following steps are recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his sedation and analgesia as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with CVVH and dialysis.
4. Monitor the patient's fever and adjust his antibiotic therapy as needed.
5. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with Epogen and transfusions as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's labile blood pressures and adjust his antihypertensive therapy as needed.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his complex medical conditions to prevent complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 61-year-old male with End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, suffered a cardiac arrest and is currently in respiratory failure. He has been agitated overnight and required increased sedation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3Â°C, heart rate of 95 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 175/87 mmHg. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O.

The patient has a history of hypertension, diarrhea, altered mental status, renal failure, and cardiac arrest. His laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 6.8 g/dL. He has been receiving various medications, including calcium gluconate, fentanyl, midazolam, KCl, and labetalol.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further deterioration of his lung function and increased risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Sepsis: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure may be indicative of sepsis, which can lead to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
3. Bleeding complications: The patient's coagulopathy, as indicated by his prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT), may increase his risk of bleeding complications.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and history of hypertension may increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
5. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state and prolonged hospitalization may increase his risk of developing infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or bloodstream infections.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may be indicative of neurological complications, such as seizures, which can worsen his condition.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea may lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, which can worsen his respiratory and cardiac function.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are essential to prevent and treat potential complications.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
   .
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and trach placement should help with this.
   - IP for trach and PEG--> need to call to assure is on schedule; if not
   will ask surgery to do procedures
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
   - He is very agitated and difficult to be weaned from the vent
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Haldol to 10mg tid
   - Seroquel can be added because QTc was normal
   - F/u EKG done today because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Chest xray this morning
   - re pan culture this morning
   - add abios if he has CXR
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - On  Epogen with HD
   - Transfused 1U PRBC's
   - Will continue to monitor
   .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Continue on PRN IV labetalol because pressures are labile and cannot
   prescribe standing dose.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   .
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal) NPO
   for placement
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: ART line placed [**12-1**], R PICC placed [**11-23**], and new L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.

Based on the patient's 24-hour progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent due to mental status, and agitation is a major hindrance to weaning from the vent. The patient's respiratory status is also complicated by bibasilar atelectasis and possible pneumonia.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but is agitated and difficult to assess. Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation, and the patient has had a staring spell that was concerning for continued seizures.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is unclear, and it is unlikely that he will regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis. The patient's renal function is being managed with CVVH, and there are concerns about the effectiveness of the current treatment.
4. Fever: The patient has had a long course of antibiotics for a positive blood culture, and there is concern about the possibility of sepsis.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is chronic and stable, but it is unclear whether it is related to renal disease or ACD.
6. Labile blood pressures: The patient has been intermittently hypotensive and hypertensive, and there is concern about the possibility of an infectious source or hypovolemia.
7. Endo: The patient has elevated PTH levels, which are likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal failure. The patient is also hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic.
8. RUE swelling: The patient has a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with collaterals, which requires plasty prior to PICC removal.
9. DM type II: The patient's blood sugar levels are well-controlled with sliding scale insulin only, but there is concern about the possibility of hypoglycemia.

The patient's current plan of care includes:

1. Tracheostomy and PEG placement to help with weaning from the vent and to improve the patient's mental status.
2. Continuous EEG monitoring to assess for seizure activity.
3. Keppra load and uptitration to manage the patient's altered mental status.
4. Fentanyl and midazolam infusions to manage the patient's pain and agitation.
5. Haldol and Seroquel to manage the patient's agitation and to reduce the risk of seizure activity.
6. CVVH to manage the patient's acute renal failure.
7. Renal recommendations to continue cellcept and prednisone, and to stop calcitriol and increase aluminum hydroxide.
8. Antibiotics to manage the patient's fever and potential sepsis.
9. Close monitoring of the patient's electrolyte levels and blood pressure.
10. Consideration of moving the patient to a vent rehab unit if the tracheostomy and PEG placement are successful.

s negative to

t responsive, looks

   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro

   - Increase haldol to 10mg tid

   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following

   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
   .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   .

   .
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's current condition and potential medical complications:

Current Condition:

* The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus (DM) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and had a cardiac arrest (PEA arrest).
* The patient is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status and has a tracheostomy planned.
* He has a history of chronic anemia and is being treated with epoetin alfa (Epogen) and iron supplements.
* The patient has labile blood pressures, which are being managed with labetalol, and has a history of hyponatremia, which is being monitored.
* He has a history of fever, which is currently low-grade, and is being treated with antibiotics.
* The patient has a history of hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, which is being managed with aluminum hydroxide and calcitriol.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and weaning from the ventilator is challenging due to agitation and copious secretions.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is fluctuating, and he has had episodes of agitation, thrashing, and staring spells, which may be related to seizures or other neurological conditions.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and he is at risk for further decline in function.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is chronic and stable, but may require further treatment with epoetin alfa and iron supplements.
* Labile blood pressures: The patient's blood pressures are unstable, and he is at risk for further episodes of hypertension and hypotension.
* Fever: The patient's fever is currently low-grade, but may be a sign of a underlying infection.
* Hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia: The patient's hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia may be related to his renal failure and may require further management with medications.
* DVT and pulmonary embolism: The patient has a history of DVT and pulmonary embolism, and is at risk for further thrombotic events.
* Infection: The patient has a history of infection, and is at risk for further infections, particularly in the setting of his compromised immune system.

Based on this information, the patient's current condition and potential medical complications will require close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve his overall outcome.

Chief Complaint:
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old man with respiratory failure following a cardiac arrest. He remains agitated and requires heavy sedation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7Â°C, heart rate of 96 bpm, and blood pressure of 145/76 mmHg. He is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and analgesics.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of renal failure, with a creatinine level of 4.7 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 40 mg/dL. His electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.0 mEq/L and a phosphorus level of 5.2 mg/dL.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 98%. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's physical examination reveals distended abdomen, right and left lower extremity edema, and warm skin. His neurologic examination shows altered mental status, with no attention, no following of simple commands, and unresponsiveness.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he remains at risk for respiratory failure due to his underlying condition and the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating renal failure. This can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and other complications.
3. Sepsis: The patient's antibiotic therapy and the presence of a central line and arterial line increase his risk for sepsis.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and underlying cardiovascular disease increase his risk for further cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac tamponade.
5. Neurologic complications: The patient's altered mental status and unresponsiveness increase his risk for neurologic complications, such as seizures or brain herniation.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's distended abdomen and altered mental status increase his risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or bowel obstruction.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent these potential complications.

   FINDINGS: The previously subtotally collapsed left lung is now

   Small areas of atelectasis are limited to the basal and retrocardiac

   The free air after PEG tube placement is now evident under the right
   hemidiaphragm. The monitoring and support devices are unchanged. No

   Microbiology: [**2107-12-2**] 9:44 pm SPUTUM      Source: Endotracheal.

         >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field.    1+    (<1 per

   All new cultures are negative
   Assessment and Plan
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG
   yesterday
   - Low grade fevers, secretions on L, L lobe collapse, gm (+) cocci and
   GNR--> start VAP treatment with cefipime, linezolid, and cipro
   - weaning sedation in now that using PO haldol and seroquel.  Has been
   tolerating decrease in midaz by 2 and fentanyl by 25 every shift.  Will
   stop haldol and increase seroquel to 75 TID.
   - add methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl.
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Weaning his drip sedations now that treating with haldol and
   seroquel.
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Will get HD today and a unit of pRBC
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Start antibiotics as above.
   - tylenol
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - EPO at HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
   - guaiac stools
   - continue to monitor and consider hemolytic w/u in future
    .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.  Had to
   start labetalol drip last night because could not control BP.  Stop
   drip for HD and reassess after HD session
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Try to restart home labetalol 600mg [**Hospital1 **] after HD
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
