   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG
   yesterday
   - Low grade fevers, secretions on L, L lobe collapse, gm (+) cocci and
   GNR--> start VAP treatment with cefipime, linezolid, and cipro
   - weaning sedation in now that using PO haldol and seroquel.  Has been
   tolerating decrease in midaz by 2 and fentanyl by 25 every shift.  Will
   stop haldol and increase seroquel to 75 TID.
   - add methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl.
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Weaning his drip sedations now that treating with haldol and
   seroquel.
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Will get HD today and a unit of pRBC
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .

   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Start antibiotics as above.
   - tylenol
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - EPO at HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
   - guaiac stools
   - continue to monitor and consider hemolytic w/u in future
    .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.  Had to
   start labetalol drip last night because could not control BP.  Stop
   drip for HD and reassess after HD session
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Try to restart home labetalol 600mg [**Hospital1 **] after HD
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications may arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent due to mental status and has a history of PEA arrest. Weaning from the ventilator is hindered by his agitation, which could be due to his ETT and may require tracheostomy.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but has difficulty assessing his cortex. He has shown agitation when sedation is weaned, and there is concern for continued seizures.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's renal function is unstable, and he requires ongoing dialysis. The etiology of ARF is unclear, and it is unlikely that he will regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.
4. Fever: The patient has had a long course of antibiotics for a positive UCx, and there is concern for VAP. The addition of Linezolid for purulent appearing CVL bilaterally that have been removed may contribute to the fever.
5. Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, but there is concern for related to renal disease.
6. Labile blood pressures: The patient has been intermittently hypotensive and hypertensive, and there is concern for an infectious source or hypovolemia.
7. HypoNa: The patient has had issues with hyponatremia in the past, and it is important to continue to monitor his electrolytes.
8. Endo: The patient has elevated PTH and hypercalcemia, which is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal failure.
9. RUE swelling: The patient has RUE swelling and a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein, which may require plasty prior to PICC removal.
10. DM type II: The patient's glucose levels are well-controlled with sliding scale insulin, but there is concern for hypoglycemia surrounding cooling.

Potential medical complications that may arise in the near future include:

* Continued respiratory failure and difficulty weaning from the ventilator
* Further decline in renal function and potential need for increased dialysis
* Development of sepsis or VAP due to ongoing fever and antibiotic use
* Continued anemia and potential need for transfusions
* Hypertension and potential need for increased antihypertensive medication
* Hypercalcemia and potential need for further treatment
* RUE swelling and potential need for plasty or further treatment
* DM type II and potential need for adjustments to insulin therapy

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, lab results, and clinical status to address these potential complications and provide optimal care.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG
   yesterday
   - Low grade fevers, secretions on L, L lobe collapse, gm (+) cocci and
   GNR--> start VAP treatment with cefipime, vanc, and cipro
   - weaning sedation in now that using PO haldol and seroquel.  Has been
   tolerating decrease in midaz by 2 and fentanyl by 25 every shift
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Weaning his drip sedations now that treating with haldol and
   seroquel.
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Will get HD today and a unit of pRBC
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Start antibiotics as above.
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - EPO at HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
   - guaiac stools
   - hemolytic w/u: haptoglpobin, smear, tbili, ibili, and fibrinogen
    .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.  Had to
   start labetalol drip last night because could not control BP.  Stop
   drip for HD and reassess after HD session
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Add labetalol as need this afternoon
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line
 need new art line placed today, R PICC placed

   Code:  Full (discussed with family)

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who had a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, resulting in ventilator dependency. The patient has several active issues:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation due to mental status. Weaning from ventilation is hindered by agitation, which may be caused by the endotracheal tube (ETT). Tracheostomy is recommended to improve comfort and facilitate weaning.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but is agitated and unresponsive when sedation is weaned. He had a staring spell, which was concerning for seizures, and is currently receiving Keppra for seizure prophylaxis.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure (ARF) is likely related to the PEA arrest. He requires ongoing hemodialysis (HD) and has been experiencing labile blood pressures, which may be due to hypovolemia or an infectious source.
4. Fever: The patient has had a prolonged course of antibiotics for a positive urine culture (UCx) and has developed purulent appearing central venous lines (CVL) bilaterally, which have been removed.
5. Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, which may be related to renal disease or ACD (autoimmune hemolytic anemia).

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's agitation and unresponsiveness may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and purulent appearing CVLs may indicate sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Renal failure: The patient's ARF may worsen, requiring more frequent or longer HD sessions.
4. Bleeding: The patient's labile blood pressures and possible sepsis may increase the risk of bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient's CVLs and ETT may become infected, leading to sepsis.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and staring spell may indicate neurological complications, such as seizures or encephalitis.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's labile blood pressures and possible sepsis may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure the best possible outcome.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities, including acute respiratory failure, hypertension, altered mental status, acute renal failure, and acidosis. The patient underwent a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) insertion yesterday, and has been receiving mechanical ventilation support.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 102.1Â°F, blood pressure of 158/68 mmHg, heart rate of 88 bpm, and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy at a fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) of 0.4, and has been on assist-control ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 7.0 g/dL, and renal failure, with a creatinine level of 3.7 mg/dL. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated at 12.2 K/uL, and the patient has a fever, with a temperature of 102.1Â°F.

The patient's diagnosis is acute respiratory failure, hypertension, altered mental status, acute renal failure, and acidosis. The patient's treatment plan includes mechanical ventilation support, antibiotics for suspected pneumonia, and dialysis for renal failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's respiratory failure and prolonged mechanical ventilation make them at risk for VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, elevated white blood cell count, and positive blood cultures make them at risk for sepsis.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) if not managed properly.
4. Cardiac arrest: The patient's hypertension and cardiac arrest history make them at risk for cardiac arrest.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications.
6. Acidosis: The patient's anion gap acidosis may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and prolonged hospitalization make them at risk for infection.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and sedation make them at risk for neurological complications, such as delirium or seizures.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
   # New spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs scheduled
   - ID consult, will appreciate their recs in terms of managing ABx and
   also helping find a source.
   - Surface echo to eval for vegetations.
   - will likely need to pull PICC and replace with new R IJ CVL
 now
   that pt is no longer intubated with ETT, he is not drooling as much,
   and hopefully line infxn with drool will not be an issue as it was in
   past. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the PICC, see below under
   less active/stable issues.
   - ABx as started yesterday: Cefipime, Linezolid, Cipro for L lobe
   collapse, GPC and GNR's on sputum
   - Consider broadening with Flagyl to cover anaerobes and gut flora
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Consider stopping the Keppra --> talk to Neuro about this first
   though
   - No more transfusions for now
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   - [**Male First Name (un) **]
t give Labetalol while pt hypotense
   - Pt continues on Levophed for now, if unable to wean, would consider
   adding Vasopressin
   - Consider CT thorax to look for source
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG
   yesterday
   - Will defer trach mask trials/RSBI/SBT's in the setting of active
   febrility
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation. Currently off the Versed and using only
   Fentanyl and scheduled Seroquel. Stopped Haldol yesterday
   - Have added methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl.
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - Had HD yesterday
   - F/u with renal about next HD
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Renal recs stopping AlOH and starting Renagel today 800 tid
 will
   do this today
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Doesn't appear to be DIC, or hemolysis
   - EPO at HD
   - Had 1U PRBC transfusion yesterday
   - guaiac stools
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Hold Labetalol for low bp's and give prn for elevated bp's.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.

    Active issues at this point:
   # New spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with

   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs scheduled
   - ID consult, will appreciate their recs in terms of managing ABx and
   also helping find a source.
   - Surface echo to eval for vegetations.
   - will likely need to pull PICC and replace with new R IJ CVL
 now
   that pt is no longer intubated with ETT, he is not drooling as much,
   and hopefully line infxn with drool will not be an issue as it was in
   past. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the PICC, see below under
   less active/stable issues.
   - ABx as started yesterday: Cefipime, Linezolid, Cipro for L lobe
   collapse, GPC and GNR's on sputum
   - Consider broadening with Flagyl to cover anaerobes and gut flora
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Consider stopping the Keppra --> talk to Neuro about this first
   though
   - No more transfusions for now
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   - [**Male First Name (un) **]
t give Labetalol while pt hypotense
   - Pt continues on Levophed for now, if unable to wean, would consider
   adding Vasopressin
   - Consider CT thorax to look for source
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG
   yesterday
   - Will defer trach mask trials/RSBI/SBT's in the setting of active
   febrility
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation. Currently off the Versed and using only
   Fentanyl and scheduled Seroquel. Stopped Haldol yesterday
   - Have added methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl.
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - Had HD yesterday
   - F/u with renal about next HD
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Renal recs stopping AlOH and starting Renagel today 800 tid
 will
   do this today
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Doesn't appear to be DIC, or hemolysis
   - EPO at HD
   - Had 1U PRBC transfusion yesterday
   - guaiac stools
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Hold Labetalol for low bp's and give prn for elevated bp's.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only

   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a prolonged course of antibiotics for a positive urine culture (UCx) and was recently intubated due to cardiac arrest. He has been experiencing fevers, hypertension, and altered mental status. His current issues include:

1. Infection: The patient has a positive sputum culture and a history of antibiotic use, which may have contributed to the development of an infection. The source of the infection is unclear, but it may be related to the PEG tube or a blood transfusion reaction.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent due to his altered mental status and agitation, which is making it difficult to wean him off the ventilator.
3. Altered mental status: The patient has been experiencing agitation, thrashing, and drooling, which is making it difficult to assess his cortex. He has a history of seizures and was recently started on Keppra.
4. Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, which may be related to his renal disease or ACD.
5. Labile blood pressures: The patient has been experiencing intermittent hypotension and hypertension, which may be related to his infection or hypovolemia.
6. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and his renal function is likely to remain unstable.
7. Endocrine issues: The patient has hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, which may be related to his renal failure.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's infection may progress to sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to hypoxia and respiratory arrest.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's altered mental status and agitation may lead to cardiac arrest.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and altered mental status may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Renal failure progression: The patient's renal failure may worsen, leading to end-stage renal disease.
6. Hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia: The patient's endocrine issues may worsen, leading to further complications.
7. Infection-related complications: The patient's infection may lead to complications such as abscesses, osteomyelitis, or septic shock.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's assessment and plan are as follows:

1. Continue antibiotics for the infection and monitor for signs of sepsis.
2. Wean the patient off the ventilator when his mental status improves.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressures and adjust his medication as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his medication as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust his medication as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's endocrine issues and adjust his medication as needed.
7. Consider a tracheostomy and PEG tube placement to improve the patient's respiratory and nutritional status.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a prolonged course of antibiotics for a positive urine culture and was recently intubated due to respiratory failure. He has been experiencing fevers, hypertension, and altered mental status. The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and has been treated with multiple medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and antihypertensives.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient's fevers and positive sputum cultures suggest a possible infection, which could be caused by a variety of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, or fungi.
2. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure has been consistently elevated, which could lead to end-organ damage and complications such as cardiac failure, stroke, or renal failure.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status could be caused by a variety of factors, including infection, medication side effects, or underlying neurological disorders.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could be caused by a variety of factors, including pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
5. Renal Failure: The patient's ESRD could be exacerbated by his ARF, which could lead to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and anemia.
6. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest suggests that he may be at risk for future cardiac events, which could be exacerbated by his hypertension, electrolyte imbalances, and underlying cardiac disease.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's PEG placement and history of gastrointestinal bleeding suggest that he may be at risk for further gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or obstruction.
8. Hemolytic Reaction: The patient's recent blood transfusion and history of anemia suggest that he may be at risk for a hemolytic reaction, which could be caused by a variety of factors, including blood type incompatibility or medication side effects.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature, blood pressure, and mental status closely to identify any potential complications.
2. Consider broadening the patient's antibiotic coverage to include anaerobes and gut flora, given his recent gastrointestinal procedures.
3. Continue to wean the patient off sedatives and analgesics, while closely monitoring his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
4. Consider placing a tracheostomy tube to facilitate weaning from the ventilator.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent complications.
6. Consider referring the patient to a nephrologist for further management of his ESRD.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and consider further imaging or endoscopy to evaluate for any potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities, including:

1. Renal failure, acute respiratory failure, and hypotension, indicating severe organ dysfunction.
2. Fever, anemia, and rising WBC, suggesting sepsis or infection.
3. Abdominal tenderness and free air in the abdomen, possibly related to a recent PEG placement.
4. Mental status alteration, with decreased responsiveness, likely due to delirium in the setting of fever.
5. Respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.
6. Cardiac arrest, hypertension, and hypotension, indicating cardiovascular instability.
7. Anemia, potentially related to blood loss or underlying chronic disease.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or cardiovascular collapse.
2. Infection-related complications, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or bacteremia.
3. Hemodynamic instability, including hypotension or hypertension, which can lead to organ hypoperfusion or failure.
4. Respiratory failure, including ARDS, which can require prolonged mechanical ventilation and increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
5. Cardiac arrest, which can lead to permanent damage or death.
6. Anemia, which can exacerbate cardiovascular instability and increase the risk of bleeding.
7. Renal failure, which can require dialysis and increase the risk of electrolyte imbalances, acid-base disorders, and cardiovascular complications.

The patient's current treatment plan includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressors, and mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and frequent reassessment are necessary to prevent further deterioration and optimize treatment outcomes.

s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the

s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should

s negative to

t responsive, looks

   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the

s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should

s an older line) and

   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG placed
   on [**12-2**].
   - Pressure support trial
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure

d haldol previously)

   - Renal is following

3. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes and agitation.
4. Altered mental status: The patient has been agitated and unresponsive, with difficulty weaning from sedation.
5. Cardiac arrest: The patient had a recent cardiac arrest, which may have contributed to his current condition.
6. Renal failure: The patient has ESRD and is receiving hemodialysis.
7. Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, which may be related to his renal disease.
8. Labile blood pressures: The patient has had intermittent episodes of hypotension and hypertension.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 7.0-7.2 g/dL

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Cardiac arrest
* Renal failure
* Anemia

* Managing hypertension and labile blood pressures
* Monitoring for signs of cardiac arrest and renal failure
* Managing anemia and electrolyte imbalances

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a prolonged course of antibiotics for a positive urine culture (UCx) and was recently intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has been experiencing spiking fevers, hypotension, and altered mental status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Infection: The patient's spiking fevers and hypotension suggest the possibility of a severe infection, which could be caused by a variety of pathogens, including bacteria, fungi, or viruses.
2. Blood transfusion reaction: The patient received a blood transfusion yesterday, and the possibility of a febrile transfusion reaction cannot be ruled out.
3. Drug reaction: The patient was recently started on Keppra, and the possibility of a drug reaction cannot be ruled out.
4. TTP (thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura): Although less likely, TTP should be considered as a potential cause of the patient's symptoms.
5. Abdominal perforation: The patient's recent placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube and the presence of free air under the diaphragm suggest the possibility of an abdominal perforation.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and the possibility of pneumonia or other respiratory complications should be considered.
7. Cardiac arrest: The patient's recent cardiac arrest and the presence of a prolonged QT interval on his EKG suggest the possibility of cardiac complications.
8. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is a significant concern, and the possibility of chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease should be considered.
9. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and the presence of a staring spell suggest the possibility of neurological complications, including seizures or encephalopathy.
10. Hemolytic reaction: The patient's recent blood transfusion and the presence of hemolytic anemia suggest the possibility of a hemolytic reaction.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics for his suspected infection, including Cefipime, Linezolid, and Zosyn.
2. Sedation: The patient is receiving sedation with propofol, versed, and fentanyl to manage his agitation and discomfort.
3. Analgesia: The patient is receiving analgesia with morphine and methadone to manage his pain.
4. Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation to support his respiratory function.
5. Renal replacement therapy: The patient is receiving hemodialysis to manage his acute renal failure.
6. Blood transfusions: The patient received a blood transfusion yesterday and may require additional transfusions in the future.
7. Neurological monitoring: The patient is receiving neurological monitoring, including continuous EEG, to monitor for seizures or other neurological complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve his outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with chronic renal failure (CRF) who suffered a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure. He has been on various antibiotics, including ciprofloxacin, linezolid, and cefepime, and has developed a fever of 101.8Â°F. He is receiving mechanical ventilation and has been prescribed inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis against Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP). His renal function is stable, and he will receive hemodialysis today. He has altered mental status and is being treated with keppra for possible seizures. He has ST elevations on his electrocardiogram (ECG) in the setting of hypertension, but it is not likely due to unstable plaque.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's increased secretions and white blood cell count (WBC) may indicate the development of VAP, which could be treated with vancomycin and Zosyn as per ID recommendations.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and altered mental status may indicate the development of sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's CRF and recent PEA arrest may put him at risk for AKI, which could worsen his renal function.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's ST elevations on his ECG and hypertension may indicate the development of cardiac arrhythmias, which could worsen his condition.
5. Seizures: The patient's altered mental status and possible seizures may indicate the development of seizure disorders, which could worsen his condition.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he develops VAP or other respiratory complications.
7. Infection: The patient's fever and altered mental status may indicate the development of infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
8. Bleeding: The patient's prolonged bleeding time and low platelet count may indicate the development of bleeding complications, which could worsen his condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   # New spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Spiking fevers up to 103.3.
   - CT with contrast to investigate possible abdominal process; renal ok
   with IV and po contrast, given graft failure
   - f/u C. diff and fungal cultures
   - Initiate Bactrim; confirm dosing with ID or pharmacy
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs scheduled
   - D/C zosyn and vancomycin (slow infusion given history of rash)
   - Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl
   - f/u ID consult; ask about investigating possible sinus infection and
   treatment
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   - Consider stopping the Keppra --> talk to Neuro about this first
   though
   - no beta-blockers
   - Wean off Levophed as tolerated
   - Add on beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and prednisone)
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG placed
   on [**12-2**].
   - d/c Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation and attempt to wean from
   vent
   - Decrease Methadone by
 dose
   - Pressure support trial
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, as above.
   - Have added methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl; wean
   to 7.5mg tid; wean to half dose (11mg daily).
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Doesn't appear to be DIC, or hemolysis
   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD yesterday; HD vs. CVVH tomorrow
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - AlOH discontinued previously
   - On Renagel 800 tid.  D/C Sevelemer and initiate Amphagel.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Hold Labetalol for low bp's and give prn for elevated bp's.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - Increase ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.
   Nutrition:
   NovaSource Renal (Full) - [**2107-12-5**] 04:50 AM 40 mL/hour
 continue
   current tube feeds

s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the

s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should

   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Spiking fevers up to 103.3.
   - CT with contrast to investigate possible abdominal process; renal ok

ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl

s an older line)

s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever

t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG placed

 dose

    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a prolonged course of antibiotics for a positive urine culture (UCx) and was recently intubated due to a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. He has been experiencing spiking fevers, hypotension, and respiratory failure. His mental status is altered, and he has been agitated and unresponsive to sedation.

The patient has a history of chronic anemia, which is stable, and acute on chronic renal failure. He has been on dialysis and has had multiple central lines placed. He has also had a PEG tube placed.

The patient's current laboratory results show:

* WBC: 14.5
* Hct: 24.5
* Plt: 265
* Cr: 4.4
* TropT: 0.18
* TCO2: 31
* Glucose: 159

The patient's medications include:

* Zosyn
* Vancomycin
* Famotidine
* Carafate
* Heparin
* Keppra
* Methadone
* Fentanyl
* Cellcept
* Prednisone
* Renagel
* AlOH

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning from sedation and ventilator
* Increasing Keppra dose
* Adding beta-glucan and galactomannan
* Continuing cellcept and prednisone
* Monitoring for sepsis and adjusting antibiotics as necessary
* Considering stress dose prednisone if HD unstable
* Monitoring for DVT and VAP

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's spiking fevers and hypotension may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he is not weaned from the ventilator or if his lung function deteriorates.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if he continues to experience blood loss or if his bone marrow function is impaired.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen if he does not receive adequate dialysis or if his kidney function deteriorates.
5. Infection: The patient's positive sputum culture and fevers may indicate a respiratory infection, which could lead to pneumonia and sepsis.
6. Hemolytic reaction: The patient's recent blood transfusion and febrile transfusion reaction may indicate a hemolytic reaction, which could lead to organ failure and death.
7. Thrombosis: The patient's history of DVT and VAP may indicate a higher risk of thrombosis, which could lead to organ failure and death.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a complex medical history, including hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease.

Current issues:

1. Fever: The patient has had a spiking fever, with a peak temperature of 103.3Â°F (39.6Â°C). The cause of the fever is unclear, but it may be related to an infection, blood transfusion reaction, or drug reaction.
2. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension, which may be related to infection, hypovolemia, or medication side effects.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent due to mental status and has had difficulty weaning from the ventilator.
4. Altered mental status: The patient has had altered mental status since the PEA arrest, with agitation and difficulty following commands.
5. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with an unclear etiology.
6. Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, with normal B12 and folate levels.
7. Labile blood pressures: The patient has had intermittently hypotensive and hypertensive blood pressures, which may be related to infection, hypovolemia, or medication side effects.
8. Endo issues: The patient has elevated PTH, hypercalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia, which may be related to renal failure.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, hypotension, and altered mental status may indicate sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
2. Blood transfusion reaction: The patient received a blood transfusion yesterday, and the fever may be related to a blood transfusion reaction.
3. Drug reaction: The patient was started on Keppra recently, and the fever may be related to a drug reaction.
4. TTP (thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura): The patient's fever, hypotension, and altered mental status may indicate TTP, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Abdominal perforation: The patient's abdominal pain and fever may indicate abdominal perforation, which can lead to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if he is unable to wean from the ventilator, leading to prolonged mechanical ventilation and increased risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
7. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen if he is unable to recover renal function, leading to increased risk of cardiovascular disease and mortality.
8. Anemia: The patient's chronic and stable anemia may worsen if he is unable to recover renal function, leading to increased risk of cardiovascular disease and mortality.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's fever, blood pressure, and mental status.
2. Start zosyn and vancomycin for suspected infection.
3. Continue to wean the patient from sedation and try to turn off the fentanyl.
4. Consider adding vasopressin to support blood pressure.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dialysis as needed.
6. Consider stress dose prednisone if the patient becomes unstable during dialysis.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider EPO at HD.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's labile blood pressures and adjust medication as needed.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex medical case with multiple issues, including fever, hypotension, respiratory failure, altered mental status, renal failure, anemia, and labile blood pressures. The patient's condition is unstable, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent potential medical complications.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
   # New spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs scheduled
   - Start zosyn and vancomycin (slow infusion given history of rash)
   - D/c cipro and linezolid and flagyl
   - f/u ID consult
   - will likely need to pull PICC (febrile, and it
s an older line) and
   replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the PICC,
   see below under less active/stable issues; also difficulty with CVL
   placement. Hold for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Consider stopping the Keppra --> talk to Neuro about this first
   though
   - F/u with Heme Onc about the smear that was collected, specifically
   looking for shistos
   - no beta-blockers
   - Pt continues on Levophed for now, if unable to wean, would consider
   adding Vasopressin
   - Add on beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and prednisone)
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.  Trach and PEG placed
   on [**12-2**].
   - Pressure support trial
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, try to turn off the fentanyl. Currently
   off the Versed
   - Seroquel (have d/c
d haldol previously)
   - Have added methadone 10mg TID to assist with weaning fentanyl; wean
   to 7.5mg tid.
   - F/u EKG daily because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   -          f/u EKG
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD today
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - AlOH discontinued previously
   - On Renagel 800 tid
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Doesn't appear to be DIC, or hemolysis
   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive.
   - Keep watching pressures
   - Hold Labetalol for low bp's and give prn for elevated bp's.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - Increase ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic renal failure. The patient has been experiencing fevers, hypotension, and respiratory failure, and is currently ventilator-dependent.

Active issues:

1. Infection: The patient has a new spiking fever, and his blood cultures are positive for Micrococcus and Staphylococcus aureus. He has also had a recent sputum culture that grew out Micrococcus and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia. The patient's ID consult is pending.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent due to his altered mental status and respiratory failure. He has had a CT scan that showed possible pneumonia, but the results are pending.
3. Altered mental status: The patient has been experiencing agitation and thrashing around when his sedation is weaned. He has also had a staring spell that was concerning for seizures.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood cultures and fevers suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may lead to further complications such as pneumonia, respiratory acidosis, and respiratory failure.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and seizures may lead to further neurological complications such as cerebral edema, seizures, and brain death.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's hypertension and tachycardia may lead to further cardiovascular complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, and cardiac failure.
5. Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure may lead to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and uremic syndrome.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's recent PEG placement may lead to further gastrointestinal complications such as perforation, bleeding, and infection.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature, blood pressure, and respiratory status.
2. Continue to wean the patient's sedation and try to turn off the fentanyl.
3. Consider adding methadone to assist with weaning the fentanyl.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and consider adding anticonvulsants if necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider adding dialysis if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and consider adding antacids if necessary.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. Further evaluation and management are necessary to address the patient's active issues and potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are identified:

Summary:

The patient, a 61-year-old man, is critically ill and admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure following a PEA arrest. He has been febrile, requiring pressors and then weaned off. The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, end-stage renal disease, and altered mental status. He is currently unresponsive and has a fever of 103.3Â°F. The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, pain management, and anticonvulsants. He is also receiving nutritional support and has a PICC line, dialysis catheter, and arterial line.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and positive sputum cultures suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may progress to chronic respiratory failure if not managed effectively.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's end-stage renal disease may worsen if not managed with dialysis or other renal replacement therapies.
4. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest increases his risk of future cardiac arrests, particularly if not managed with adequate cardiovascular support.
5. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may progress to delirium if not managed with adequate sedation and pain control.
6. Infection: The patient's positive sputum cultures suggest the possibility of infection, which may lead to further complications if not managed effectively.
7. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's nutritional support may not be adequate to meet his needs, leading to deficiencies and further complications.
8. Medication-Related Complications: The patient's medication regimen may lead to complications, such as increased risk of bleeding with anticoagulation therapy or increased risk of seizures with anticonvulsants.
9. Pressure Ulcers: The patient's immobility and altered mental status may increase his risk of developing pressure ulcers.
10. DVT: The patient's immobility and altered mental status may increase his risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT), particularly if not managed with adequate prophylaxis.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   # New spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Spiking fevers up to 103.3.
   - CT with contrast to investigate possible abdominal process; renal ok
   with IV and po contrast, given graft failure
   - f/u C. diff and fungal cultures
   - Initiate Bactrim; confirm dosing with ID or pharmacy
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs scheduled
   - D/C zosyn and vancomycin (slow infusion given history of rash)
   - Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl
   - f/u ID consult; ask about investigating possible sinus infection and
   treatment

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a complex medical history, including hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease. The patient has been intubated and is currently on a ventilator due to respiratory failure.

The patient's recent events include:

* Development of spiking fevers, hypotension, and respiratory failure
* Positive sputum cultures for Staphylococcus aureus and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia
* CT scan showing a small IVC thrombus and diffuse mesenteric stranding
* Initiation of heparin drip and Bactrim for sinus infection
* Withdrawal from Vanc/Zosyn and initiation of Cipro
* Development of altered mental status, agitation, and diaphoresis
* Initiation of Keppra for seizure prophylaxis
* Development of labile blood pressures and hypertension
* Elevation of troponin-T and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
* Development of anemia and acute kidney injury

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to bacterial infections
* Pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to IVC thrombus and diffuse mesenteric stranding
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest due to hypotension and tachycardia
* Neurological complications, such as seizures, due to electrolyte imbalance and medication side effects
* Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) due to blood transfusion reaction
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to nephrotoxic medications and hypovolemia
* Hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia due to insulin and glucose control issues
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea and constipation, due to medications and underlying disease
* Cardiovascular complications, such as hypertension and tachycardia, due to underlying disease and medication side effects

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for bacterial infections
* Heparin drip for IVC thrombus and DVT prophylaxis
* Bactrim for sinus infection
* Cipro for Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection
* Keppra for seizure prophylaxis
* Sedation and analgesia for agitation and discomfort
* Fluid management for hypovolemia and hypertension
* Nutrition support with tube feeds
* Glycemic control with insulin and sliding scale
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is pending clinical improvement. If the patient's tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) are successful, he may be considered for transfer to a ventricular rehabilitation unit.
