 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest during IR placement of temporary HD catheter, now
   ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units
   PRBC.  IR consulted re: possible embolization, did not feel the bleed
   was acute (felt >48 hours old) and wished to preserve hepatic artery
   and liver function if possible, so recommended monitoring Hct.  General
   surgery consulted re: possible relation to PEG placement, but did not
   believe this was [**2-7**] procedure based on the location of the hematoma.
   Recommended monitoring q6h Hct and coags, transfusing as needed and
   keeping Hct >20.  Received 1 unit PRBC yesterday
   - Monitor coags and Hct q6h, transfuse for Hct > 20; had fairly stable
   hct x 2 days, suggesting resolution of bleed with reversal of PTT/INR.
   - Active T&S; crossmatch 4 units
   .
   # Fevers: Question: sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis,
   versus hypotension secondary to blood loss.  Sputum shows GNR and GPC
   in pairs and clusters.  d/c
ed flagyl as that would double-cover with
   zosyn for anaerobes, and zosyn coverage for aspiration is adequate.  C.
   diff negative.  Continued profound increasing leukocytosis.  Last
   elevated Tm 101.9 was on [**2107-12-12**].
   - Peripheral smear, diff ordered
   - Continue empiric vancomycin and zosyn for presumed aspiration PNA
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures)
   - Change Hydrocort stress dose steroids to home Prednisone 5mg daily
   - Continue Bactrim until [**12-15**] for Stenotrophomonas
   - beta-glucan (negative) and galactomannan still pending
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   Patient on Vanc/Zosyn.  CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA but CT [**12-11**]
   showed confluent consolidative opacity of superior RLL, atelectasis vs.
   aspirationi or pneumonia.  Pt was febrile following aspiration event
   but is now afebrile. Trached.
   - today transitioned from A/C on CPAP [**5-20**]. Will cont to monitor.
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn to cover for aspiration (anaerobes)
   - Pt was NPO while acute GI problems resolve; but will start TFs slowly
   today.
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.  Although pt was put back on CMV/AC; as of
   [**12-15**] he was transitioned to CPAP.
   - ABG on CPAP as above, will cont to monitor.
   - Cont sedation with fentanyl boluses and Seroquel TID.
   .
   # Pain:  Patient clearly in pain and uncomfortable, likely due to
   stretch of hepatic capsule due to hematoma. Discontinue Morphine to 4mg
   q2h prn and dc
ed methadone. Discontinue Versed 2-4mg q4h
   - Re-start Seroquel 25mg tid
   - Fentanyl IV
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with
   coumadin.  All anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma discovered.
   Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now given liver hematoma and risk of
   bleed.
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.
   - Labetalol drip
 turned off overnight
   - Cont hydralazine Q6 hours.
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   Today, less alert and interactive.
   - Continue Keppra 500mg IV q12h
   - f/u neuro recs; Neuro re-consulted [**12-15**]
   - extra 250mg IV keppra today
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD MWF
   - Continue home does of prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if
   HD unstable. Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension
   Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with positive sputum
   Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't
   received transfusions before this), possible drug reaction (started
   Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with
   free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG placed).   Currently
   afebrile.
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.  Afebrile x 3 days as of [**2107-12-15**].
   - Pt initially required Neo (pressor) to maintain MAP > 60
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - beta-glucan (negative) and galactomannan still pending
   - Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and
   prednisone)
   - antibiotics and f/u cultures as above
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # Hyponatremia:  Check electrolytes post-dialysis.  Resolved.
   .
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, s/p aspiration pt was kept NPO but
   will re-start tube feeds today ([**12-15**]).
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID), pneumoboots
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now working, may need to be pulled due to
   fevers, and if so, will need to have new central line placed. L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this
   line given how difficult it was to place.
   .
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU care given acute developments.

   - today transitioned from A/C on CPAP [**5-20**]. Will cont to monitor.
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn to cover for aspiration (anaerobes)
   - Pt was NPO while acute GI problems resolve; but will start TFs slowly
   today.
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.  Although pt was put back on CMV/AC; as of
   [**12-15**] he was transitioned to CPAP.
   - ABG on CPAP as above, will cont to monitor.
   - Cont sedation with fentanyl boluses and Seroquel TID.
   .
   # Pain:  Patient clearly in pain and uncomfortable, likely due to
   stretch of hepatic capsule due to hematoma. Discontinue Morphine to 4mg
   q2h prn and dc
ed methadone. Discontinue Versed 2-4mg q4h
   - Re-start Seroquel 25mg tid
   - Fentanyl IV
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with
   coumadin.  All anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma discovered.
   Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now given liver hematoma and risk of
   bleed.
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.
   - Labetalol drip
 turned off overnight
   - Cont hydralazine Q6 hours.
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   Today, less alert and interactive.
   - Continue Keppra 500mg IV q12h
   - f/u neuro recs; Neuro re-consulted [**12-15**]
   - extra 250mg IV keppra today
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD MWF
   - Continue home does of prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if
   HD unstable. Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension
   Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with positive sputum
   Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't
   received transfusions before this), possible drug reaction (started
   Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with
   free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG placed).   Currently
   afebrile.
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.  Afebrile x 3 days as of [**2107-12-15**].
   - Pt initially required Neo (pressor) to maintain MAP > 60
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - beta-glucan (negative) and galactomannan still pending
   - Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and
   prednisone)
   - antibiotics and f/u cultures as above
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # Hyponatremia:  Check electrolytes post-dialysis.  Resolved.
   .
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, s/p aspiration pt was kept NPO but
   will re-start tube feeds today ([**12-15**]).
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID), pneumoboots
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now working, may need to be pulled due to
   fevers, and if so, will need to have new central line placed. L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this
   line given how difficult it was to place.
   .
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with ESRD, HTN, DM, who was admitted with dyspnea and ARF. He had a PEA arrest during IR placement of a temporary HD catheter and is now ventilator-dependent due to mental status. He has a history of liver hematoma, aspiration, and respiratory failure. He is currently on empiric antibiotics for presumed aspiration PNA, and his cultures are pending. He has also been experiencing fevers, hypotension, and altered mental status, which may be related to infection, blood transfusion reaction, or other factors.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fevers, hypotension, and altered mental status may be indicative of sepsis, which can be life-threatening if not treated promptly.
2. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient's aspiration event and positive sputum cultures may indicate the development of aspiration pneumonia, which can be a serious complication.
3. Liver Hematoma: The patient's liver hematoma may continue to bleed or become infected, which can lead to further complications.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not treated properly, leading to further complications such as ARDS.
5. DVT: The patient's DVT may continue to progress and cause further complications if not treated properly.
6. Renal Failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not treated properly, leading to further complications.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen if not treated properly, leading to further complications.
9. Endocrine Complications: The patient's elevated PTH and hypercalcemia may indicate endocrine complications, which can be serious if not treated properly.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The patient's empiric antibiotics should be continued pending culture results. The patient's liver hematoma should be closely monitored for signs of bleeding or infection. The patient's respiratory failure should be managed with close monitoring and treatment of underlying causes. The patient's DVT should be treated with anticoagulation therapy. The patient's renal failure should be managed with close monitoring and treatment of underlying causes. The patient's anemia should be treated with erythropoietin therapy. The patient's hyponatremia should be treated with electrolyte replacement therapy. The patient's endocrine complications should be managed with close monitoring and treatment of underlying causes.

Recommendations:

1. Continue empiric antibiotics pending culture results.
2. Closely monitor the patient's liver hematoma for signs of bleeding or infection.
3. Manage the patient's respiratory failure with close monitoring and treatment of underlying causes.
4. Treat the patient's DVT with anticoagulation therapy.
5. Manage the patient's renal failure with close monitoring and treatment of underlying causes.
6. Treat the patient's anemia with erythropoietin therapy.
7. Treat the patient's hyponatremia with electrolyte replacement therapy.
8. Manage the patient's endocrine complications with close monitoring and treatment of underlying causes.
9. Consider consulting with a nephrologist and an endocrinologist to further manage the patient's complex medical condition.

* Renal status: The patient is receiving hemodialysis (HD) per renal failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8Â°C (98.3Â°F), heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 150/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL and a hematocrit of 25.9%. His white blood cell count is elevated at 41.4 K/uL, and his platelet count is 355 K/uL. His liver function tests are abnormal, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 586 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 213 IU/L.

The patient is at risk for several medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a high fever and an elevated white blood cell count, which may indicate the presence of a bacterial infection.
3. Hemorrhage: The patient has a large hepatic hematoma, which may lead to bleeding complications.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, which may indicate liver failure or dysfunction.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, which may increase his risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
6. Renal failure: The patient is receiving dialysis, which may indicate kidney dysfunction or failure.
7. Thrombosis: The patient is at risk for thrombosis due to his elevated risk factors, including his age, cardiac arrest, and liver hematoma.

Based on the patient's condition, the following interventions are recommended:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Administer antibiotics to treat any potential bacterial infections.
3. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
4. Monitor the patient's hemoglobin and hematocrit levels and transfuse blood products as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
6. Continue dialysis to manage the patient's kidney function.
7. Monitor the patient's risk for thrombosis and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual who requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to manage his complex medical condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic liver disease. He was intubated due to a PEA arrest during an IR placement of a temporary HD catheter and is currently ventilator-dependent. He has been experiencing fevers, hypotension, and labile blood pressures, and has been treated with various antibiotics and anticoagulants.

The patient's recent laboratory results show:

* Leukocytosis (WBC 35.0-41.4 x 10^9/L)
* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT 390, AST 104)
* Elevated creatinine (4.8-5.7 mg/dL)
* Elevated potassium (4.0-5.5 mmol/L)
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) (104-177 mg/dL)
* Anemia (Hct 26.0-29.8%)
* Hypercalcemia (Ca++ 9.8 mg/dL)
* Hyperphosphatemia (PO4 3.6-4.8 mg/dL)

The patient's imaging studies show:

* A CT scan of the chest shows a confluent consolidative opacity of the superior right lower lobe, which may be due to aspiration or pneumonia.
* An MRI of the brain shows no signs of acute ischemia.

The patient's medical issues include:

* Aspiration pneumonitis vs. aspiration pneumonia
* Sepsis vs. hypotension secondary to blood loss
* Liver hematoma
* Acute on chronic renal failure
* DVT
* Spiking fevers, hypotension
* Anemia
* Hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia
* DM type II

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia
* Anticoagulation for DVT
* Renal replacement therapy (RRT) for acute on chronic renal failure
* Pain management
* Electrolyte management
* Glucose control
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis or septic shock
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Hepatic failure
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Electrolyte imbalances
* Infection-related complications (e.g. pneumonia, UTI)
* Bleeding complications (e.g. GI bleeding, ICH)

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to adjust his treatment plan and prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a prolonged course of treatment for a positive urine culture (UCx) with Pseudomonas and was recently started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for a suspected aspiration pneumonia. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus type II.

Current Status:

* The patient is currently intubated and on ventilator support due to respiratory failure.
* He has a significant abdominal distension and is experiencing severe pain.
* The patient's mental status has improved significantly, but he is still agitated and has difficulty following commands.
* He has a history of liver hematoma, which has resolved, but he is still at risk for bleeding.
* The patient has a DVT in several vessels, including the IVC, and is being bridged with coumadin.
* He has a history of anemia, which is likely related to his renal disease.
* The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, and he is at risk for hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.
* He has a history of hypertension, which is being managed with hydralazine.
* The patient's glucose control is suboptimal, and he is at risk for hypoglycemia.

Assessment and Plan:

* The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he still requires ventilator support.
* The patient's abdominal distension is improving, but he still has significant pain.
* The patient's mental status is improving, but he still requires close monitoring.
* The patient's DVT is being managed with coumadin, and he will need to have his PICC line removed in the future.
* The patient's anemia is being managed with EPO at HD.
* The patient's electrolyte levels are being monitored closely, and he will need to have his AlOH dose adjusted.
* The patient's hypertension is being managed with hydralazine.
* The patient's glucose control is being monitored closely, and he will need to have his insulin dose adjusted.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for developing pneumonia due to his intubation and prolonged hospitalization.
* Aspiration: The patient is at risk for aspiration due to his intubation and abdominal distension.
* Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to his liver hematoma and DVT.
* Hypocalcemia: The patient is at risk for hypocalcemia due to his electrolyte imbalance.
* Hyperphosphatemia: The patient is at risk for hyperphosphatemia due to his electrolyte imbalance.
* Hypoglycemia: The patient is at risk for hypoglycemia due to his glucose control.
* DVT: The patient is at risk for developing DVT due to his prolonged immobility and underlying medical conditions.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
* Continue to manage the patient's abdominal distension and pain with conservative measures.
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status closely and adjust his sedation as needed.
* Continue to manage the patient's DVT with coumadin and consider removing his PICC line in the future.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and adjust his AlOH dose as needed.
* Continue to manage the patient's hypertension with hydralazine and consider adjusting his dose as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's glucose control closely and adjust his insulin dose as needed.
* Consider sending the patient for a CT scan to rule out any underlying lung disease or other medical conditions.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient had an episode of aspiration during morning rounds, and although the CXR did not show clear evidence of pneumonia, the patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest the possibility of aspiration pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and positive sputum cultures suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and the possibility of respiratory failure is high due to his underlying conditions and the use of sedatives and analgesics.
4. Abdominal Complications: The patient's abdominal distension and tympanitic abdomen suggest the possibility of abdominal complications, such as chemical peritonitis, functional ileus, or intra-abdominal bleeding.
5. Liver Hematoma: The patient's liver hematoma is a significant concern, and the possibility of bleeding or further complications is high.
6. Renal Complications: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure and the need for dialysis increase the risk of renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease progression.
7. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's labile blood pressures and the use of antihypertensive medications increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as hypertension, hypotension, or cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status, seizures, and encephalopathy suggest the possibility of neurological complications, such as stroke, cerebral edema, or seizures.
9. Eye Complications: The patient's irritated eyes and the need for eye drops suggest the possibility of eye complications, such as conjunctivitis or uveitis.
10. DVT: The patient's venous thrombi in several vessels, including his IVC, increase the risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism.

Based on these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent or treat these complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the key points:

**Current Status:**

* The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute kidney injury (AKI).
* He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure.
* He has a history of chronic hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and liver disease.
* He has been experiencing fever, tachycardia, and hypertension, which are being managed with antibiotics and antihypertensive medications.
* He has a large liver hematoma, which is being monitored closely.

**Laboratory Results:**

* Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC count is elevated, and platelet count is normal.
* Blood chemistry: Serum creatinine is elevated, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is normal.
* Liver function tests: Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) are elevated, and bilirubin is normal.
* Coagulation studies: International Normalized Ratio (INR) is elevated, and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) is normal.

**Imaging Studies:**

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Shows dense right middle lobe/retrocardiac opacity, which is improving.
* Computed Tomography (CT) scan of the chest: Shows confluent consolidative opacity of the superior right lower lobe, which is likely due to aspiration or pneumonia.
* CT scan of the abdomen: Shows a large liver hematoma with scattered areas of perihepatic hematoma and scattered blood within the mesentery.

**Medical History:**

* The patient has a history of chronic renal failure, which is likely to progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
* He has a history of liver disease, which is likely to be related to his ESRD.
* He has a history of hypertension, which is being managed with antihypertensive medications.
* He has a history of diabetes mellitus type II, which is being managed with insulin and oral medications.

**Current Medications:**

* Antibiotics: Vancomycin, Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn), and Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim)
* Antihypertensive medications: Labetalol, Hydralazine, and Metoprolol
* Insulin: Long-acting insulin and sliding scale insulin
* Other medications: Sucralfate, pentamidine, and Keppra

**Plan:**

* Continue antibiotics and antihypertensive medications as prescribed.
* Monitor the patient's liver function tests and coagulation studies closely.
* Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation.
* Consider weaning the patient off sedation and monitoring his mental status closely.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medications as necessary.
* Consider performing a liver biopsy to determine the cause of the patient's liver disease.

**Potential Complications:**

* Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated WBC count suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver disease is likely to progress, and he may require liver transplantation.
* Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal failure is likely to progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD), which may require dialysis.

**Next Steps:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
* Consider performing a liver biopsy to determine the cause of the patient's liver disease.
* Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation.
* Consider weaning the patient off sedation and monitoring his mental status closely.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medications as necessary.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient has already had an episode of aspiration during morning rounds, and the CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA. However, the CT scan showed confluent consolidative opacity of the superior right lower lobe, which may indicate aspiration or pneumonia. The patient is being treated with Vanc/Zosyn, and the plan is to restart tube feeds slowly today.
2. Sepsis: The patient has been febrile, and the sputum cultures have grown GNR and coag (+) Staph. The patient is being treated with antibiotics, and the plan is to continue Vanc/Zosyn and restart Bactrim for Stenotrophomonas.
3. Liver Hematoma: The patient has a liver hematoma, which is being monitored, and the plan is to continue monitoring Hct and coags daily, with a goal Hct >28.
4. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and the plan is to continue hemodialysis (HD) three times a week, with the next HD scheduled for [**2107-12-16**].
5. DVT: The patient has venous thrombi in several vessels, including the IVC, and is being treated with heparin drip and coumadin. However, all anticoagulation was stopped when the liver hematoma was discovered.
6. Hypertension: The patient has labile blood pressures, and the plan is to continue Hydralazine Q6 hours, with a goal of stabilizing the blood pressure.
7. Pain: The patient appears to be in pain and uncomfortable, likely due to the stretch of the hepatic capsule due to the hematoma and significant abdominal distension.
8. Altered Mental Status: The patient has altered mental status, which may be due to delirium, medical condition, opioid withdrawal, or possible seizure and encephalopathy from acute liver failure or methadone use in the setting of liver failure.
9. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be due to chronic and stable anemia or related to renal disease.
10. Hypercalcemia: The patient has hypercalcemia, which may be secondary or tertiary and due to renal failure.
11. RUE Swelling: The patient has RUE swelling, which may be due to DVT or thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with +collaterals.

These are the potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's progress note.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old male with multiple problems post-cardiac arrest, including respiratory failure, ongoing fevers, and a large hepatic hematoma. The patient's mental status has improved over the past 24-36 hours, correlating with improved abdominal examination, lower white blood cell count, and improved fever curve.

The patient is mechanically ventilated with a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and has a SpO2 of 99%. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3Â°C, heart rate of 84 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 133/85 mmHg.

The patient has a history of allergies to vancomycin and has received antibiotics including Bactrim, vancomycin, and piperacillin/tazobactam. The patient is also receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 35.8 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 281 x 10^9/L. The patient's liver function tests are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 390 U/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 104 U/L.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Delirium/confusion
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Hepatic hematoma/blood loss anemia
* Altered mental status
* Hypertension
* Fevers and elevated white blood cell count
* Thromboses
* Chronic renal failure (CRF) requiring hemodialysis (HD)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and the patient is mechanically ventilated. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99%, but the patient's respiratory status is at risk due to the presence of respiratory failure.
2. Hepatic hematoma/blood loss anemia: The patient has a large hepatic hematoma, which can lead to blood loss anemia and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Thromboses: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin, but the patient's risk of thromboses is high due to the presence of a large hepatic hematoma.
4. Chronic renal failure (CRF): The patient is requiring hemodialysis (HD), which is a high-risk procedure for patients with CRF.
5. Infections: The patient has a history of fevers and elevated white blood cell count, which may indicate the presence of an infection.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is at risk for cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac failure.
7. Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status, which may be due to the presence of a large hepatic hematoma, respiratory failure, or other underlying conditions.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential medical complications.

**Summary of Progress Note:**

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute kidney injury (AKI). He has a history of chronic hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease. The patient underwent a temporary hemodialysis catheter placement, which was complicated by a PEA arrest during insertion. He was intubated and ventilator-dependent due to mental status.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Ventilator-dependent with CPAP/PSV mode, SpO2 100%, and RSBI 46.
* Neuro: Delirious with intact brainstem reflexes, but difficult to assess cortex. He has been experiencing agitation, thrashing, and not following commands.
* Cardiovascular: Hypertensive with a blood pressure of 166/63 mmHg, and labile blood pressures.
* Abdominal: Distended and tense, with a large liver hematoma and scattered areas of perihepatic hematoma on CT abdomen.
* Renal: Acute on chronic renal failure, with an uncertain etiology. He is receiving continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) and has been bridged with coumadin.
* Hematological: Thrombi in several vessels, including the inferior vena cava (IVC). He was on a heparin drip, but anticoagulation was stopped due to the liver hematoma.
* Infectious: Sputum cultures show growth of Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, and the patient has been treated with Bactrim and Zosyn.
* Pain: The patient appears to be in pain and discomfort, likely due to the stretch of the hepatic capsule and abdominal distension.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient has had episodes of emesis and aspiration, which may lead to pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and positive sputum cultures suggest the possibility of sepsis.
3. Liver failure: The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are improving, but he still has a large liver hematoma, which may lead to liver failure.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent and has a history of respiratory failure.
5. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and agitation may be due to delirium, which may be caused by his underlying medical conditions, medications, or infection.
6. Thrombosis: The patient has thrombi in several vessels, which may lead to further complications if not managed appropriately.

**Plan:**

1. Continue ventilator support and monitor the patient's respiratory status.
2. Manage the patient's delirium with sedation and antipsychotic medications.
3. Monitor the patient's liver function and hematoma, and consider further interventions if necessary.
4. Continue antibiotic therapy for the patient's suspected aspiration pneumonia.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his dialysis regimen as necessary.
6. Consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent further thrombosis.
7. Continue pain management and monitor the patient's comfort level.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute kidney injury (AKI). He had a prolonged ICU stay and was treated for various complications, including respiratory failure, delirium, and liver hematoma. The patient had a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and was on chronic hemodialysis (HD) prior to his current admission.

Current Status:

The patient is currently ventilator-dependent and has a tracheostomy in place. He has a liver hematoma, which is resolving, and is being treated with anticoagulation therapy. The patient has a history of delirium and is currently on Keppra for seizure prophylaxis. He has a DVT in his IVC and is being bridged with coumadin. The patient's Hct is currently 27.6% and his platelet count is 269.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Aspiration pneumonitis vs. aspiration pneumonia: The patient had emesis during morning rounds and aspirated tube feeds. He is at risk for aspiration pneumonitis or pneumonia, and his CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA, but his CT scan shows confluent consolidative opacity of the superior RLL, which may indicate aspiration or pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis and is currently being treated for a possible infection. He has a fever and leukocytosis, and his sputum cultures are positive for GNR and coag (+) staph.
3. Liver failure: The patient has a liver hematoma and is at risk for liver failure. His INR is currently elevated, and he is being treated with anticoagulation therapy.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently ventilator-dependent and has a history of respiratory failure. He is at risk for further respiratory complications, including pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
5. DVT: The patient has a DVT in his IVC and is being bridged with coumadin. He is at risk for further thrombotic events and may require anticoagulation therapy.
6. Hemolytic reaction: The patient has a history of hemolytic reaction and is at risk for further hemolytic episodes. His Hct is currently 27.6%, and his platelet count is 269.

Plan:

1. Continue anticoagulation therapy for the patient's liver hematoma and DVT.
2. Monitor the patient's Hct and platelet count closely and transfuse as necessary.
3. Continue respiratory support with the ventilator and wean as tolerated.
4. Monitor the patient's temperature and leukocytosis and treat any signs of infection.
5. Continue seizure prophylaxis with Keppra.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function tests (LFTs) and treat any signs of liver failure.
7. Continue hemodialysis (HD) as prescribed.
8. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and treat any imbalances.
9. Continue to hold tube feeds and monitor the patient's nutritional status.
10. Consider consult with a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the patient's abdominal distension and constipation.

 DELIRIUM / CONFUSION
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest during IR placement of temporary HD catheter, now
   ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   Patient on Vanc/Zosyn.  CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA but CT [**12-11**]
   showed confluent consolidative opacity of superior RLL, atelectasis vs.
   aspirationi or pneumonia.  Pt was febrile following aspiration event
   but is now afebrile on Vanc/Zosyn x 3 days.  However, sputum from [**12-13**]
   still growing Stenotrophomonas despite a course of Bactrim which
   finished [**12-15**].
   - Re-start Bactrim x14 day course, day 1=[**12-16**] to d/c [**12-30**]; appears
   Bactrim may not have been given at the correct times after HD and may
   have been dialyzed off in the past
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn to cover for aspiration (anaerobes) for a 7 day
   course, currently day 5 on [**12-16**], d/c on [**12-18**] -> will d/c today
   - Trach mask today as much as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers: Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with
   positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U
   yesterday, hasn't received transfusions before this), possible drug
   reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal
   perforation with free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG
   placed).  Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx
   about 2 wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added
   for purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of
   the CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future
   (febrile, and it
s an older line) and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to
   talk to IR about pulling the PICC, but holding for now given vascular
   complexity.  Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic
   reaction to blood transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still
   possible?  Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept
   and prednisone).  On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60.
   Question: sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus
   hypotension secondary to blood loss.
   .
   Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs and clusters.  d/c
ed flagyl as that
   would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and zosyn coverage for
   aspiration is adequate.  C. diff negative.  Continued profound
   increasing leukocytosis. Last elevated T on [**2107-12-12**] (101.9).
   Leukocytosis resolved following discontinuation of steroids.  Multiple
   C. diff toxins negative, will d/c Flagyl.  Afebrile.
   - Given elevated WBC count and long term abxs, have started empiric
   coverage for C. diff colitis.  Will also send C. diff toxin x 3 and
   will stop tx if all negative.  Despite multiple negative C. diff
   studies, will continue Flagyl as patient is clinically improving on his
   current antibiotic regimen and Flagyl may be treating an occult
   infection.
   - send another c.diff
   - Continue vancomycin/zosyn for presumed aspiration PNA as above
 can
   d/c today [**12-18**]
   - Continue Bactrim as above for Stenotrophomonas
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures, aspergillus study)
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis. As of today ([**12-15**]), transitioned from AC
   to CPAP.
   - Trach mask planned for most of today, as tolerated
   - Pt has not received Fentanyl IV for >48 hours, will keep as prn but
   minimize use
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.  On
   [**12-14**], Labetalol was d/c
ed and Hydralazine standing was started.
   - Continue Hydralazine Q6 hours; once BP stabilizes, consider
   transitioning to BP medication such as CCB or BB (hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) 239**]
   given acute on chronic renal failure) without the risk of rebound
   hypertension, given the patient
s history of labile BPs.
   - Changed Hydrocort stress dose steroids to home Prednisone 5mg daily
   - start Atenolol 25mg Qday
   - Plan to dc hydralazine/labetolol ASAP
   .
   # Abdominal Distension:  Patient
s abdomen continues to be distended
   and tympanitic, recent CT abdomen [**12-11**] showed large liver hematoma with
   scattered areas of perihepatic hematoma and scattered blood within the
   mesentery but without definite sites of active extravasation.
   Distension likely [**2-7**] chemical peritonitis which is resolving following
   reversal of anticoagulation vs. functional ileus/[**Last Name (un) **]
s syndrome
   from infection/sepsis, intra-abdominal bleed, narcotic use, or
   respiratory failure.  This is consistent with the patient
s continued
   +bowel sounds and leukocytosis, but CT abdomen did not show dilated R
   side of colon and loops of bowel were read to be wnl.  Currently
   improved abdominal pain and minimally improved distension, and abd much
   less tense than prior.  However, pt has had nausea with tube feeds and
   was only able to tolerate 2 hours of TF yesterday ([**12-17**]).
   - Monitor and manage conservatively for now, given patient
s underlying
   conditions are slowly resolving and he is clinically improving
   - Ok to restart tubefeeds but slowly
   - Will start Reglan 2.5mg TID standing for treatment of presumed
   diabetic gastroparesis
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units
   PRBC.  IR consulted re: possible embolization, did not feel the bleed
   was acute (felt >48 hours old) and wished to preserve hepatic artery
   and liver function if possible, so recommended monitoring Hct.  General
   surgery consulted re: possible relation to PEG placement, but did not
   believe this was [**2-7**] procedure based on the location of the hematoma.
   Recommended montoring q6h Hct and coags, transfusing as needed and
   keeping Hct >20.  Received 1 unit PRBC but has had stable Hct since,
   suggesting resolution of bleed with reversal of PTT/INR.
   - daily HCT
   - Monitor coags and Hct daily, goal Hct >28
   - Active T&S
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 500 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Today,
   the patient is not alert or interactive.  Neurology recommended 24 hour
   EEG monitoring, which was performed [**12-15**] with results pending.  On
   [**12-14**], the patient became significantly less agitated and was responsive
   and conversant, obeying commands and expressing intact cognition.
   Likely causes are delirium [**2-7**] medical condition and opioid withdrawal,
   and possible seizure and encephalopathy from acute liver failure or
   methadone use in the setting of liver failure.
   - Continue Keppra 500mg IV q12h; extra 250mg IV keppra with HD.
   - f/u neuro recs; Neuro re-consulted [**12-15**], completed 24 hour video EEG
   monitoring.  Will follow up on results.
   .
   # Injected, Irritated Eyes:  Ophtho consulted, recommended eye drops.
   Improving.
   - Continue eye drops per Ophtho
   .
   # Pain:  Patient appears in pain and uncomfortable, likely due to
   stretch of hepatic capsule due to hematoma and significant abdominal
   distension.  Discontinued Morphine, Methadone, and Versed.  Initiated
   on Fentanyl IV.
   - Pt has not been receiving Fentanyl IV for >24 hours, and will
   minimize use for patient comfort
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD per renal, next HD [**2107-12-16**] (MWF)
   - Continue home does of prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if
   HD unstable. Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid, Sevelemer 30.
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He was on a heparin drip, being bridged with
   coumadin.  However, all anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma
   discovered.  Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now given liver hematoma
   and risk of bleed.
   - Will need to re-address the issue of anti-coagulation for the
   patient
s multiple thrombi but will hold off on this discussion until

   - consult heme-onc today for anti-coag recs

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest during IR placement of temporary HD catheter, now
   ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   Patient on Vanc/Zosyn.  CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA but CT [**12-11**]
   showed confluent consolidative opacity of superior RLL, atelectasis vs.
   aspirationi or pneumonia.  Pt was febrile following aspiration event
   but is now afebrile on Vanc/Zosyn x 3 days.  However, sputum from [**12-13**]
   still growing Stenotrophomonas despite a course of Bactrim which
   finished [**12-15**].
   - Re-start Bactrim x14 day course, day 1=[**12-16**] to d/c [**12-30**]; appears
   Bactrim may not have been given at the correct times after HD and may
   have been dialyzed off in the past
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn to cover for aspiration (anaerobes) for a 7 day
   course, currently day 5 on [**12-16**], d/c on [**12-18**] -> will d/c today
   - Trach mask today as much as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers: Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with
   positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U
   yesterday, hasn't received transfusions before this), possible drug
   reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal
   perforation with free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG
   placed).  Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx
   about 2 wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added
   for purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of
   the CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future
   (febrile, and it
s an older line) and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to
   talk to IR about pulling the PICC, but holding for now given vascular
   complexity.  Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic
   reaction to blood transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still
   possible?  Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept
   and prednisone).  On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60.
   Question: sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus
   hypotension secondary to blood loss.
   .
   Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs and clusters.  d/c
ed flagyl as that
   would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and zosyn coverage for
   aspiration is adequate.  C. diff negative.  Continued profound
   increasing leukocytosis. Last elevated T on [**2107-12-12**] (101.9).
   Leukocytosis resolved following discontinuation of steroids.  Multiple
   C. diff toxins negative, will d/c Flagyl.  Afebrile.
   - Given elevated WBC count and long term abxs, have started empiric
   coverage for C. diff colitis.  Will also send C. diff toxin x 3 and
   will stop tx if all negative.  Despite multiple negative C. diff
   studies, will continue Flagyl as patient is clinically improving on his
   current antibiotic regimen and Flagyl may be treating an occult
   infection.
   - send another c.diff
   - Continue vancomycin/zosyn for presumed aspiration PNA as above
 can
   d/c today [**12-18**]
   - Continue Bactrim as above for Stenotrophomonas
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures, aspergillus study)
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis. As of today ([**12-15**]), transitioned from AC
   to CPAP.
   - Trach mask planned for most of today, as tolerated
   - Pt has not received Fentanyl IV for >48 hours, will keep as prn but
   minimize use
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.  On
   [**12-14**], Labetalol was d/c
ed and Hydralazine standing was started.
   - Continue Hydralazine Q6 hours; once BP stabilizes, consider
   transitioning to BP medication such as CCB or BB (hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) 239**]
   given acute on chronic renal failure) without the risk of rebound
   hypertension, given the patient
s history of labile BPs.
   - Changed Hydrocort stress dose steroids to home Prednisone 5mg daily
   - start Atenolol 25mg Qday
   - Plan to dc hydralazine/labetolol ASAP
   .
   # Abdominal Distension:  Patient
s abdomen continues to be distended
   and tympanitic, recent CT abdomen [**12-11**] showed large liver hematoma with
   scattered areas of perihepatic hematoma and scattered blood within the
   mesentery but without definite sites of active extravasation.
   Distension likely [**2-7**] chemical peritonitis which is resolving following
   reversal of anticoagulation vs. functional ileus/[**Last Name (un) **]
s syndrome
   from infection/sepsis, intra-abdominal bleed, narcotic use, or
   respiratory failure.  This is consistent with the patient
s continued
   +bowel sounds and leukocytosis, but CT abdomen did not show dilated R
   side of colon and loops of bowel were read to be wnl.  Currently
   improved abdominal pain and minimally improved distension, and abd much
   less tense than prior.  However, pt has had nausea with tube feeds and
   was only able to tolerate 2 hours of TF yesterday ([**12-17**]).
   - Monitor and manage conservatively for now, given patient
s underlying
   conditions are slowly resolving and he is clinically improving
   - Ok to restart tubefeeds but slowly
   - Will start Reglan 2.5mg TID standing for treatment of presumed
   diabetic gastroparesis
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units
   PRBC.  IR consulted re: possible embolization, did not feel the bleed
   was acute (felt >48 hours old) and wished to preserve hepatic artery
   and liver function if possible, so recommended monitoring Hct.  General
   surgery consulted re: possible relation to PEG placement, but did not
   believe this was [**2-7**] procedure based on the location of the hematoma.
   Recommended montoring q6h Hct and coags, transfusing as needed and
   keeping Hct >20.  Received 1 unit PRBC but has had stable Hct since,
   suggesting resolution of bleed with reversal of PTT/INR.
   - daily HCT
   - Monitor coags and Hct daily, goal Hct >28
   - Active T&S
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 500 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Today,
   the patient is not alert or interactive.  Neurology recommended 24 hour
   EEG monitoring, which was performed [**12-15**] with results pending.  On
   [**12-14**], the patient became significantly less agitated and was responsive
   and conversant, obeying commands and expressing intact cognition.
   Likely causes are delirium [**2-7**] medical condition and opioid withdrawal,
   and possible seizure and encephalopathy from acute liver failure or
   methadone use in the setting of liver failure.
   - Continue Keppra 500mg IV q12h; extra 250mg IV keppra with HD.
   - f/u neuro recs; Neuro re-consulted [**12-15**], completed 24 hour video EEG
   monitoring.  Will follow up on results.
   .
   # Injected, Irritated Eyes:  Ophtho consulted, recommended eye drops.
   Improving.
   - Continue eye drops per Ophtho
   .
   # Pain:  Patient appears in pain and uncomfortable, likely due to
   stretch of hepatic capsule due to hematoma and significant abdominal
   distension.  Discontinued Morphine, Methadone, and Versed.  Initiated
   on Fentanyl IV.
   - Pt has not been receiving Fentanyl IV for >24 hours, and will
   minimize use for patient comfort
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD per renal, next HD [**2107-12-16**] (MWF)
   - Continue home does of prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if
   HD unstable. Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid, Sevelemer 30.
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He was on a heparin drip, being bridged with
   coumadin.  However, all anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma
   discovered.  Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now given liver hematoma
   and risk of bleed.
   - Will need to re-address the issue of anti-coagulation for the
   patient
s multiple thrombi but will hold off on this discussion until
   next week, after the patient has been stable for another several days
   - consult heme-onc today for anti-coag recs
   .
   Less active issues:
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachycardia and hypertensive.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Resolved. Had u/s that did not completely visualize
   subclavian vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had
   PICC placed yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic
   vein with +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - [**Hospital1 **] insulin
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO, PMV use as tolerated.
   Restarting tubefeeds today.
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID), pneumoboots
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now working, may need to be pulled due to
   fevers, and if so, will need to have new central line placed. L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this
   line given how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU care continues given acuity of illness; discuss rehab
   placement with case management<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient had emesis during morning rounds and aspirated tube feeds, which led to a risk of aspiration pneumonitis vs. aspiration PNA. The patient is currently on vancomycin and zosyn, which may not be adequate coverage for aspiration PNA.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a high fever, leukocytosis, and positive sputum cultures, which may indicate sepsis. The patient is on empiric coverage for C. diff colitis, but the diagnosis is not yet confirmed.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent due to mental status and has a history of respiratory failure. The patient's respiratory status is improving, but there is still a risk of respiratory failure.
4. Liver Hematoma: The patient has a large liver hematoma, which may lead to bleeding, liver failure, or other complications.
5. Delirium: The patient has altered mental status, which may be due to medical condition, opioid withdrawal, or encephalopathy.
6. DVT: The patient has venous thrombi in several vessels, including his IVC, which may lead to pulmonary embolism or other complications.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be related to chronic kidney disease, ACD, or other causes.
8. Endo: The patient has elevated PTH, which is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal failure.
9. RUE Swelling: The patient had RUE swelling, which has resolved, but may still have underlying DVT or other complications.
10. DM Type II: The patient has DM type II, which may lead to hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia, or other complications.

To manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management by the healthcare team. The patient's care plan should include:

1. Continued respiratory support and monitoring for respiratory failure.
2. Empiric coverage for aspiration PNA and sepsis, pending culture results.
3. Monitoring of liver function and hematoma size.
4. Management of delirium with sedation and other interventions as needed.
5. Anticoagulation therapy for DVT, pending consultation with hematology.
6. Management of anemia with EPO and other interventions as needed.
7. Monitoring of endo status and adjusting AlOH therapy as needed.
8. Monitoring of RUE swelling and DVT, pending further evaluation.
9. Management of DM type II with insulin therapy and other interventions as needed.

The patient's care plan should be regularly reviewed and updated to ensure that all potential complications are addressed and managed effectively.

   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachycardia and hypertensive.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Resolved. Had u/s that did not completely visualize
   subclavian vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had
   PICC placed yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic
   vein with +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - [**Hospital1 **] insulin
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO, PMV use as tolerated.
   Restarting tubefeeds today.
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID), pneumoboots
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now working, may need to be pulled due to
   fevers, and if so, will need to have new central line placed. L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this
   line given how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted to the ICU with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He had a recent PEA arrest during the placement of a temporary hemodialysis catheter and is now ventilator-dependent due to his mental status.

Current status:

* The patient's mental status has improved, and he is now able to follow commands and respond to his environment.
* His respiratory status has also improved, and he is no longer hypoxic.
* His abdominal distension has improved, and he is now able to tolerate tube feeds.
* His liver hematoma is stable, and his coagulation studies are normal.
* His hemoglobin is 10.7 g/dL, and his platelet count is 335,000/mm3.
* He has a history of diabetes mellitus type II and is currently receiving insulin therapy.
* He has a history of hypertension and is currently receiving antihypertensive medication.

Potential medical complications:

* Aspiration pneumonia: The patient had emesis during morning rounds and aspirated tube feeds, which may have led to the development of aspiration pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The patient has a fever and leukocytosis, which may be indicative of sepsis.
* Liver failure: The patient has a liver hematoma and is at risk of developing liver failure.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure and is at risk of developing chronic kidney disease.
* DVT: The patient has a history of DVT and is at risk of developing further thrombotic events.
* Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia and is at risk of developing further anemia due to his underlying medical conditions.

Plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and respiratory status closely.
* Continue to manage his abdominal distension and liver hematoma conservatively.
* Continue to manage his anemia with erythropoietin therapy.
* Continue to monitor his coagulation studies and platelet count closely.
* Continue to monitor his renal function and adjust his dialysis therapy as needed.
* Consider consulting with a nephrologist to discuss the patient's renal function and potential need for further dialysis therapy.
* Consider consulting with a cardiologist to discuss the patient's cardiac status and potential need for further cardiac therapy.
* Consider consulting with a gastroenterologist to discuss the patient's abdominal symptoms and potential need for further gastrointestinal therapy.

His respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and he is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 399 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.3 g/dL, elevated white blood cell count, and liver function tests indicating liver dysfunction. His coagulation profile is abnormal, with an international normalized ratio of 1.4 and a partial thromboplastin time of 30.9 seconds.

The patient's physical examination is significant for a non-tender abdomen, distended abdomen, and right lower extremity edema. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is receiving oxygen therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
2. Hepatic hematoma: The patient's large hepatic hematoma is a significant risk factor for bleeding and potential complications.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding and inadequate treatment.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's abnormal coagulation profile may increase the risk of bleeding and thrombosis.
5. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and ongoing fevers suggest a potential infection, which may require further investigation and treatment.
6. Sepsis: The patient's systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) criteria are met, and there is a risk of developing sepsis.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and ongoing hypertension may increase the risk of further cardiovascular complications.
8. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and there is a risk of further deterioration in renal function.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and inadequate nutrition may lead to malnutrition and related complications.

In summary, the patient is critically ill with multiple comorbidities and potential complications. Further monitoring and treatment are necessary to manage his condition and prevent potential complications.
